title: smart motorways must go
story: Last week the Members of the House of Commons Transport Select Committee published their report on Smart Motorways, telling Ministers that no more should be opened until there is data to prove that they are safer than traditional motorways. The report also called for the building of more refuge areas to ensure that drivers breaking down would never be more than a mile from such a place. There was also a dignified demonstration in which families of those who had lost loved ones in live lane crashes carried coffins outside Parliament. Those families and the Members of the Commons Transport Select Committee are clearly objectively right.  Breaking down on a motorway is a very unpleasant experience, but at least on a normal motorway one can usually get one’s car onto the hard shoulder and take refuge oneself behind a stout barrier.A year ago Transport Secretary Grant Shapps ordered that no more motorways should be designated as “Smart” before new software to detect broken down vehicles had been installed.  However, it is also essential that there should be somewhere safe not only for the driver of a broken down vehicle, but for any passengers, especially any disabled or wheelchair users and children including those in prams or carry cots. The trouble is that designating a motorway as “Smart” costs nothing, but enables the Transport Department to claim that an extra lane has been put in place.It is a life threatening nonsense that should be ended.I wrote a fortnight ago about the  prosecution of former soldier Dennis Hutchings for murder over a death in Northern Ireland almost half a century ago.  That trial came to an end when Hutchings, who was 80 years old and in ill health with kidney failure died during his trial last week. Initially the Army refused to allow his former Regiment, The Life Guards, to provide pall bearers, but then came a change of mind and Hutchings’ coffin was borne to his grave by men of that Regiment.Despite the sacrifices made by men such as Hutchings and despite Tony Blair’s deals which he hoped would end  the “troubles”,  a double decker bus was hijacked and set on fire in Newtownards last week.  Nichola Mallon, the Social Democratic and Labour Party infrastructure Minister rightly described the culprits as “cowards with covered faces who had done nothing more than attack their own community.”   Sadly there seems to an ongoing supply of such men who see themselves not as cowards, but as heroes.It was yet another Irish tragedy that Airey Neave the heroic escapee from Coldritz Castle, the most secure prison in Nazi Germany, who would have been Margaret Thatcher’s Secretary of State for Northern Ireland was murdered on the eve of General Election victory of 1979.  He understood that there is but one way to deal with terrorists.Both as a member of the House of Lords and because I would count myself as something of a friend of Owen Paterson and his late wife, I have to be careful what I say about the circumstances leading up to her suicide and his resignation from the House of Commons.  The latter was. I think, in the best interests of both Paterson and his family.The is nothing wrong with a Member of Parliament accepting money for giving advice on government policy to commercial businesses.  The more difficult area is where a Member is paid to tell Government Ministers of the effect of Government policy on a business or a whole industry. Even more so when the Member urges ministers to adopt or change policies in a way that would benefit that commercial interest which is paying him. That is to become a lobbyist.Above all it is essential that the Member ensures that both the Minister and his relevant civil service advisers know of his financial interest.But I hope that Sir Keir Starmer and his Opposition colleagues will pause and think before they wade in with cries of “Tory Sleaze”.    In the event that Labour came into office their Ministers would be lobbied by Labour members pushing private interests, not least those of trades unions.There are a good many sensible Labour Members of the Commons, even more in the Lords who should think about these matters and quietly discuss them, not just between themselves but with Ministers too.More from NewsThere is no such thing as too much Agatha ChristieSecret to mastering golf - play with your other handWednesday evening UK news briefing: MPs who break rules must be &#39punished&#39 says Boris Johnson amid Geoffrey Cox rowWhy the traditional Anchorman could be a dying breedBarbican to weed out racism after some staff presumed ‘all black artists smoke cannabis’‘I’ve collected more than £1million for the Poppy Appeal over the last 75 years – it’s my duty’More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: traditional anchorman could dying breed
story: Newsreading is “an occupation for an articulated suit”, according to Jeremy Paxman. “Do you remember reading aloud at school? That’s what it is. I don’t think it has any grandeur or skill. Any fool can do it.”It’s a sentiment echoed by John Ryley, the head of Sky News, who recently declared the end of the era of the “all-powerful anchor” reporters were now experts. The future of news, he explained, is digital, with the headlines available on mobile phones whenever the viewer chooses, rather than delivered – with a bong of Big Ben – on the hour.In perhaps not unconnected news, Adam Boulton, the channel’s editor-at-large this week announced that he is to leave after 33 years.In Boulton’s words, that means he and fellow Sky News anchor Dermot Murnaghan have “had our day.”As Boulton’s long innings at Sky comes to an end, over at New Broadcasting House, a different endgame seems to be playing out around Edwards. The Welshman’s situation is different – he’s still very much employed – but the image he cuts is of a man so miserable with his lot, it’s almost painful to watch.In August, he told Radio Cymru he is considering his future presenting the nightly news – after 20 years, he said mournfully, it can be “taxing”. “Now that a big milestone is here, which is 60 years old, it’s natural for a man to think: ‘Am I going to continue in this job for another five years, or do I want to do something different?’”In recent months, Edwards has seemed to take an almost mischievous delight in antagonising his employer on social media. In March, after BBC Breakfast presenters Naga Munchetty and Charlie Stayt had their wrists slapped for appearing to laugh at housing secretary Robert Jenrick’s prominent union flag, Edwards posted an image of him in front of the Welsh flag alongside the caption: “Flags are now mandatory – very pleased with my new backdrop for BBC News at Ten”. When he was ordered to take down the post, he responded: “Gutted. My pro-flag tweet has been cut down in its prime. By order.”Last week, he skirted the corporation’s rules on impartiality again, after positing his concerns over the National Museum of Wales taking down a portrait of the slave trader Sir Thomas Picton. “As a journalist, I feel uneasy about this element of ‘censoring’ history,” he tweeted. “Should not Picton remain on display as a reminder to Wales of an aspect of its past – no matter how disgraceful?”Even discussing Remembrance Sunday this week, Edwards managed to slip in a sly reference to a possible departure. “Every year, I feel humbled by the sight of veterans and their families, proud and dignified, often mourning the loss of comrades or loved ones,” he told the Radio Times. “I will still be attending long after my BBC duties are done.”Boulton believes men like him have had their run – but you feel that Edwards is convinced he’s got a lot yet to offer. He is reported to have sounded out ITV to see if he could fill Piers Morgan’s empty chair – now occupied by the sprightly 65-year-old Richard Madeley.Sources claimed Edwards, in an exceptionally unusual move, hoped to maintain his position as the BBC’s go-to presenter for national events including general elections and Royal occasions. Perhaps unsurprisingly, talks did not materialise into a job offer. The  has contacted the BBC about these apparent ambitions, but the corporation “does not comment on rumour”.Certainly, BBC colleagues would not be too sad to see Edwards go. One said he was “part of a group of middle-aged men in news with egos the size of planets”. There was spluttering when he gave a recent interview complaining that colleagues had received pay rises while his own salary had been cut (from a highest level of £550,000-£599,999, to between £465,000 and £469,999 in 2019-2020), to help tackle gender pay differences at the BBC). “The reaction among the rest of us was: Huw, you earn more than £400,000 a year. Honestly, shut up,” said one long-standing BBC presenter.Would he be welcomed elsewhere in the industry? “There has been a huge swirl around Huw, but I don’t get where he thinks his market value is,” says one senior ITN figure.At the crux of all this is a delicate question: is there a place in primetime news for middle-aged, white, male behemoths like Boulton and Edwards? Boulton touched on it his interview, hinting that “television is very sensitive to the idea of ersity” – but in this case that ersity cuts both ways. The old-school anchorman may be a target of ire behind the scenes due to his Establishment background and accompanying ego, yet Boomers can play the ‘-ism’ card as well as anyone, and ageism is never a good look.Perhaps that’s why it’s taking so long for the guard to change. Or maybe the anchormen are just too expensive. Industry observers suggest that in days gone by, someone would have put a gentle hand on the shoulder of an unwanted newsreader and suggested he play a few more rounds of golf. Today, it would take a HR machine – and, you suspect, a hefty severance package – to achieve the same outcome.Anchors-in-waiting include Reeta Chakrabati, filling in on the News at One, Six, Ten and the weekends the BBC Breakfast team of Louise Minchin, Naga Munchetty and current Strictly contestant Dan Walker and even the Newsnight team of Faisal Islam, Emily Maitliss and Emma Barnett. Although what Paxman would make of such a move is probably not even for the ears of podcast listeners.For the older anchor, the equation is complicated. Boulton is right when he says that it’s older people who watch TV: data from from Enders Analysis shows that, before lockdown (when everything got thrown up in the air), the average age of the BBC One viewer was 61, ITV’s was 60, Channel 4’s was 55 even E4, a youth spin-off from Channel 4, mainly attracted 42-year-olds. How do these channels appeal to a fresh cohort without alienating the existing viewers – especially in news, which is traditionally shunned by younger people? And anyway, is it really the case that we only want to watch our own age group tell us about important things?Fortunately, there is a very simple way of measuring this. YouGov has a running “popularity and fame” tracker, updated quarterly and based on “millions of responses from the British public”. Edwards currently ranks 88th on the list of Popular Contemporary TV personalities poor old Boulton comes in at 436th.So, who is the most famous, the most popular and the most-loved TV personality in the country? Who can it be who is loved by 65 per cent of millennials, 84 per cent of Gen-Xers and 89 per cent of Boomers? It’s white, Oxford-educated, 95-year-old Sir David Attenborough. Sir Trevor McDonald, the 82-year-old who presented his final News at Ten on ITV in 2008, comes in second.Breaking news – there is life in old dogs yet.More from NewsThere is no such thing as too much Agatha ChristieSecret to mastering golf - play with your other handWednesday evening UK news briefing: MPs who break rules must be &#39punished&#39 says Boris Johnson amid Geoffrey Cox rowBarbican to weed out racism after some staff presumed ‘all black artists smoke cannabis’‘I’ve collected more than £1million for the Poppy Appeal over the last 75 years – it’s my duty’World’s longest serving female sailor has spent just one day at sea – and ‘didn’t like it much’More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: worlds longest serving female sailor has spent just one day
story: A Wren has been awarded the Guinness World Record for the longest serving female sailor despite only ever spending one day at sea.Warrant Officer Class One Barbara McGregor left the Royal Navy having served 43 years and 189 days.WO1 McGregor joined the Women’s Royal Naval Service (officially known as the Wrens) on July 26 1977, and planned to stay for just four years to enjoy a bit of sport and adventure.Joining 16 years before women were allowed to go to sea, she chose to remain on shore-based postings.“I did spend a day at sea while I was serving in Gibraltar,” she said, “and I didn’t like it much”.“It’s a different world now. If I was 18 years old again I would probably leap at the chance to go to sea.”She completed her specialist training as a communicator at HMS Mercury (now closed) near Petersfield where she and her fellow trainees were inspected by Lord Mountbatten on the day before her 18th birthday.“He wasn’t what I expected - much less formal and quite a slight figure. He got everyone to gather around him where he told us stories of his naval experiences,” she told Navy News.“A couple of years later I was on duty at HMS Dryad when the signal came through that he’d been killed. It broke my heart.”As a communicator it was WO1 McGregor’s job to pass that news on – and other important signals, instructions and messages – to ships, submarines and units scattered around the globe.This painstaking and laborious job is largely replaced today by email which can be dispatched and read in a matter of seconds.Her citation from the Guinness World Records office read: ‘The longest career in the navy (active dutyservice) (female) is 43 years 189 days, achieved by Barbara Mary McGregor (UK) from 26 July 1977 to 31 January 2021.’More from NewsThere is no such thing as too much Agatha ChristieSecret to mastering golf - play with your other handWednesday evening UK news briefing: MPs who break rules must be &#39punished&#39 says Boris Johnson amid Geoffrey Cox rowWhy the traditional Anchorman could be a dying breedBarbican to weed out racism after some staff presumed ‘all black artists smoke cannabis’‘I’ve collected more than £1million for the Poppy Appeal over the last 75 years – it’s my duty’More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: 6 ways cop26 agreement been
story: ways COP agreement has been branded too weak to tackle climate changeWorld leaders are talking about how to save the planet - and have come up with a draft text as Boris Johnson made a gloomy announcement at a press conference. But what does the COP deal mean - and why’s it being branded a ‘fudge’ Boris Johnson speaking today at the COP summit in Glasgow Image: Getty ImagesByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Nov | commentsBoris Johnson dashed to the COP summit in Glasgow today as he warned of “colossal” impactstalks fail.The Prime Minister admitted there is a huge amount to do and talks have now entered the hard yards”. He claimed the world is “closer than it has ever been” to kick-starting the “beginning of the end” of man-made climate change. But he added: “It’s very frustrating to see countries that have spent six years conspicuously patting themselves on the back… edging towards default now vulnerable nations are demanding payment, here, now in Glasgow.”The gathering of nearly  nations is meant to finish on Friday - though could run into Saturday - and has produced a draft of its overall agreement. The cover decision - issued six hours later than planned after late-night talks - reaffirms pledges to limit global temperature rises and cut emissions.It will now be discussed by all the countries involved in the UN summit and likely watered down before it can be rubber-stamped at the end of the week. But after Greta Thunberg accused world leaders of “blah blah”, campaigners are warning it simply doesn’t go far enough on the key issues of our time. Former MP Gordon Brown said the draft agreement was “an admission of prospective failure” - as it accepts that another meeting is required to agree on key pledges.He suggested Boris Johnson was treating the event “like a day trip”, and urged him to remain in Glasgow until the end of the summit to strike a deal. Shadow business secretary Ed Miliband added: Itaposs hard to avoid the suspicion that the Prime Minister sees a day trip to the Cop as a useful way of distracting from the sleaze surrounding the Tory Party rather than a chance to get a grip and engage in the substance like a statesman. Greenpeace today claimed the document was especially worrying because it is already “weak” - and will normally become weaker as it’s negotiated into something all nations can accept. So what does the agreement actually say and what are the biggest holes in it  Here’s a brief explainer…We’ll have to go back againIn fairness, the main goal of COP was never to limit global temperature rises to .C in one fell swoop - only to keep the dream “alive”. But the document lays bare just how much more work there is to do, despite two weeks of talks in Glasgow and side deals on coal, cars, cash and trees. The document urges sluggish countries to submit their updated climate plans as soon as possible before November  - after they missed a deadline to get them over this autumn. And it calls for another meeting of world leaders in  to give updated pledges. .C may be on le supportThe draft cover text “reaffirms” the  Paris Agreement - but that only ever pledged to “pursue efforts” to limit global temperature rises to .C. It does not go further and commit countries to hold the increase this century below .C. Indeed, it “expresses alarm and concern that human activities have caused around . °C of warming to date”. And Boris Johnson said of the .C target: “I think it’s in the balance… we’re now finding things tough. But it doesn’t mean it’s impossible. The draft document does call for “meaningful and effective action by all Parties in this critical decade” - including a % cut in carbon dioxide emissions by . But John Ashton, a former climate change envoy for the UK government, warned: “Thereaposs a huge gap between the pledges and the plans that are on the table and whataposs actually needed to keep .C on the table. “Itaposs a very dangerous and delicate situation for the negotiators. The whole thing will be balanced on a kne edge.”Coal and fossil fuels ‘not good enough’UK officials hailed parts of the draft text, including a proposed commitment to accelerate the phasing-out of coal and subsidies for fossil fuels. There has been a deal for many developed countries to stop using coal by the s and others by the s.But Labour argues this has been watered down from hard dates of  and  - and doesn’t include China, the US, India or Australia.Greenpeace added the draft of the final decision “completely fails to mention fossil fuels”, adding: “The first draft of the climate pact text is already exceptionally weak. Usually the text starts with some ambition, which then gets watered down. “To keep . alive, four words must be added: ‘fossil fuels phase out’, and countries must come back next year to close the gap.” Net Zero doesn’t have a firm dateUK officials were pleased with net zero commitments from India, Thailand, Nepal, Nigeria and Vietnam - with % of the world now offering them. But India has only pledged Net Zero by , which a UK official branded “curious” and predicted will sht forward. China, Russia and Saudi Arabia have all chosen  instead while Turkey has chosen . And the draft only commits to “net zero around mid-century” rather than a hard  date. Labour also says there are holes in the pledges, such as Australia committing to  but planning for  in line with a C world - or Saudi Arabia increasing oil production this decade.We still aren’t at billionThe text calls for “beyond” bn a year of climate finance. But the bn target was due in  and still hasn’t been hit, with it now projected to be met in  or . COP has seen fresh commitments from the UK, Spain, Japan, Australia, Norway, Ireland and Luxembourg. And the UK has pledged £.bn overall from  to . But Nick Dearden, director of Global Justice Now, said: “Many countries are unable to pull out all the stops because they still havenapost received the climate finance promised for more than a decade.”Deforestation nations covering % of global forests signed a declaration to “halt and reverse” deforestation by . The UK said it was the biggest breakthrough on forests in a generation and a “massive success for COP”, while Boris Johnson said it would “end this great chainsaw massacre”. In the draft text it’s worded a little bit more generally - saying “protecting and restoring forests” is important to cut emissions. But almost immediately there were questions about how the plan will be enforced. Nations pledged in  to halve tropical deforestation by , but a report this year found it has increased. Less than  hours after the announcement, Boris Johnson accepted some governments might “break the pledges”. And Indonesia’s forestry minister said the  promise was “unfair”, despite his government signing it. news politics mandatory-covid-vaccines-could-cost-"Sajid Javid announces mandatory vaccines for frontline workersByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsMandatory Covid jabs could cost the NHS up to , frontline staff, the government’s own impact statement suggested today. The Department of Health and Social Care accepted there may be a “signicant” hit to the health service workforce as millions are told ‘no jab, no job’.Ministers today announced patient-facing healthcare staff in England will need to have had both doses of vaccine by April , unless they have a medical exemption, as a condition of deployment.That includes doctors, nurses and dentists as well as cleaners, porters, ward clerks and receptionists. Private healthcare, unpaid volunteers, agency staff and trainees are all included.Health Secretary Sajid Javid said the scales clearly tip to one side for mandatory jabs - due to our imperative to protect the NHS and those services upon which we all rely.But a government impact statement has now estimated , health and care staff could refuse to be vaccinated under the policy, without having a medical exemption.  That includes , staff in the NHS in England in a central scenario - .% of the workforce. It also includes , in private healthcare . And it includes , in social care , where jabs will become mandatory this Thursday. Once natural wastage is included the government estimates this figure at more like ,. The documents do not make clear whether all , staff would be working on the frontline currently. It appears possible that some are already in back office roles. Itaposs thought patient-facing staff who refuse to be jabbed will face being reassigned to back office roles or losing their jobs completely. The impact statement confirmed hospitals will have to pay for “recruiting replacements for workers who may not fulfil the requirement of having both doses of the vaccine”. This in turn could cause “potential disruption to health and care services”.  The impact statement warned there was a wide range of possibilities of how many health and care staff will get vaccinated in response to the scheme - anywhere from , to ,.It said there is signicant uncertainty about the final number of staff affected. However, it added: The impact on workforce levels and health and care services could be signicant. If a proportion of staff decides to leave the NHS, this would put pressure on NHS services. This is likely to be more acute in clinical staff groups where there are existing staff shortages and lags in labour supply caused by education and training requirements, but all services are likely to be impacted.It comes after unions and Labour warned of possible staff shortages.UNISON today warned some care homes could be forced to shut their doors and others will struggle to meet safe staffing levels.  On the NHS changes, UNISON head of health Sara Gorton added: This wasn’t something the government needed to do. “The effective and supportive approach taken by NHS trusts has persuaded the overwhelming majority of health staff to have both Covid shots. “Now this sledgehammer policy risks doing more harm than good. “Without knowing what proportion of staff are covered by exemptions, creating a new law seems extreme. “It will move effort and attention away from caring for Covid patients and clearing the backlog created by the pandemic.” Shadow Health Secretary Jon Ashworth warned ministers to “proceed with caution”, adding: We simply cannot afford to lose thousands of NHS staff overnight. Some MPs sounded caution over the move - but others said it should have happened quicker. Tory MP Dr Andrew Murrison said: “If this has to be done, then it is better to do it quickly, and by the Spring, clearly we’re going to be past the winter pressures we’re all concerned about.” Mr Javid warned it cannot be business as usual when it comes to vaccination, adding: The first duty of everyone working in health and social care is to avoid preventable harm to the people they care for. “Not only that, they have a responsibility to do all they can to keep each other safe.” But Rachel Harrison of the GMB union warned: Bulldozing this vaccine will exacerbate the already crushing staffing crisis we face across the NHS and ambulance services. Both are operating under extreme pressures, after a decade of austerity and cuts, with an exhausted and demoralised workforce who are fearful of what is to come as we head through winter. Staff are already leaving their employment and this will certainly force many more to go. Royal College of Nursing General Secretary Pat Cullen added: The vast majority of NHS nursing staff received the COVID- vaccine as soon as it was offered, having led the vaccination roll out across the UK and continuing to do so with the booster programme. “With the five months until this decision takes effect, the government and employers must continue to engage with the small minority who have chosen not to have the vaccine. “This is vital to understanding their concerns, supporting them to understand the importance of the vaccine and to make that important choice. Comment MORE ON Rachel HarrisonAndrew MurrisonPat CullenJonathan AshworthUnisonConservative PartyNHSRoyal College of NursingGMB unionHospitalsCare homesNursing homesPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: sajid javid needs vax vow
story: Sajid Javid needs vax vow Plan B - sacking , staff would cripple servicesConservative Health Secretary Sajid Javid needs a Plan B as his vow to sack up to , health and care staff and NHS staffthey do not get the jab would plunge the sector deeper into crisisHealth Secretary Sajid Javid needs a Covid jab Plan B for the NHS Image: PAopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Nov | comments Sacking up to , health and care staff, including , NHS workers, would endanger lives and cripple services. So Sajid Javid needs a Plan Bhis drive to force all health and care workers in England to be Covid jabbed plunges a sector, already troubled by vacancies, deeper into crisis.Imposing deadlines for care workers on Thursday and those in the NHS on April Fool’s Day next year is a gamble for the Conservative Health Secretary – and it’s one that isn’t being followed in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland. We believe carers and health workers should be jabbed to protect the vulnerable, but daily tests need to be considered as an alternative for the unvaccinated or care might collapse.Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section When the real world collides with ministerial diktats, ordinary people are the victims. Greed rules IF £, Conservative second jobber Geoffrey Cox has not broken the rules, Westminster’s rules are wrong. Boris Johnson ’s seeming indference about one of his MPs earning a fortune outside Parliament is a green light for greed. Perhaps the reason the Prime Minister isn’t going to bother even speaking to Cox, a lawyer and former Attorney-General, is because Johnson dismissed £, he received from a second job of his own as “chicken feed”, betraying how out of touch he really is. The Conservative sleaze scandal has revealed a self-entitled elite demonstrating it is in power not for what it can do for the country but what the country can do for Tory MPs. Top MarcsFairness campaigner Marcus Rashford dedicating his MBE to his mother was a Manchester United and England footballer hitting the back of the net again.Mum Melanie Maynard, who brought up five children while working full-time on the minimum wage and had a charity foodbank warehouse named in her honour, can be as proud of her boy as any parent ever could be. Comment MORE ON Conservative PartyNHSPoliticsCoronavirus vaccineCoronavirusSajid Javid MP" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: top tory paid betting industry
story: Top Tory paid by betting industry urged ministers to reject gambling crackdownLaurence Robertson is paid £, a year by the Betting and Gaming Council and has been given free tickets to sporting events by betting companiesLaurence Robertson is paid £, a year by the Betting and Gaming CouncilByRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Nov | commentsA top Tory paid £-an-hour by the betting industry warned ministers in Parliament not to back tough new laws on gambling. According to parliamentaposs register of interests, Laurence Robertson is paid £, a year by the Betting and Gaming Council, an industry body that lobbies on behalf of bookmakers. In the past year, Mr Robertson has also been given free tickets by betting companies to horse-racing at Ascot, Test matches at Lord’s and England games at Wembley. He has also earned £, a month for ten hours’ work as the BGC’s “parliamentary adviser on sport and safer gambling”. While being employed by the BGC, he has spoken at least three times in parliament in defence of the gambling industry. In the past year, the Tewkesbury MP told ministers there is a “great danger” that a crackdown on gambling could push players to the black market and argued against greater regulation of the industry, the Times reported. Mr Robertson denies any conflict of interest. Last December, when the governmentaposs gambling review was announced, Mr Robertson demanded that the review was “evidence-based, consistent and balanced”. In July he said thatnew laws were “too stringent” then there would be “a great danger” that people would play on the black market and he told ministers that they needed to be “careful” about introducing new laws that could exacerbate the “worrying trend” of illicit gambling. In September, after the appointment of a new minister, he again said that the government review would be “evidence-based and evidence-led”.  It came as it was revealed Tory MPs wrote “sponsored content” for a lobbying group that backs the gambling industry, according to a report in the . They include government aide and Stoke South MP Jack Brereton, who penned an article for Conservative Home urging ministers to ensure the gambling review does “nothing to put the industry’s competitiveness at risk”. He also heaped praise on betting company Bet for the “huge economic contribution that the betting giant makes to our constituencies” including “high skilled, good quality jobs”. “It should also not be forgotten that Bet and its founders are the highest taxpayers in the UK, paying some £.m to the Treasury in   – money which will have helped fund vital public services like health and education, not just in Stoke-on-Trent but across the whole country,” the article said. The politicians were not paid for writing, but it is reported the Betting and Gaming Council paid the ConservativeHome website through an advertising agency for the space. One of the Tory MPs, Philip Davies wrote an article labelled “sponsored by the Betting and Gaming Council” that appeared on ConservativeHome in April. In June, he declared a ticket and hospitality box at Ascot Races with a value of £, paid for by the Betting and Gaming Council, in the MPs’ register of interests. The MP for Shipley did not comment when approached by the Mirror. Other Tory MPs who wrote sponsored content for the Betting and Gaming Council include Greg Smith, MP for Buckingham, who wrote a piece headlined “Betting shops are helping the high street get back on its feet” in June. His spokesperson said it was unpaid. Meanwhile, Workington MP Mark Jenkinson wrote a sponsored piece in July, saying he had “grave concerns about calls by some anti-gambling campaigners that limits should be placed on how much iniduals should be allowed to bet”. Jenkinson also declared a ticket and hospitality box at Ascot Races in June, with a value of £,, paid for by the Betting and Gaming Council. He did not respond to requests for comment. Mr Brereton also did not respond to requests for comment. Bet is a major employer in his constituency. A ConservativeHome spokesperson said: “Just like the , ConservativeHome carries advertising, which helps to provide high quality journalism for free to millions of readers each year.” It is understood ConservativeHome does not commission sponsored pieces but they are booked by advertisers via an agency in common with other media sources. Separately, the register of interests shows that ten MPs accepted tickets to Euro  football matches from betting companies.Eight Conservatives and two Labour MPs were gted tickets worth between £,. and £,.Matt Zarb-Cousin, from the campaign group Clean Up Gambling, said: The amount the gambling industryaposs spent on hospitality for MPs is an indication of how desperate they are to make some friends in Parliament. But putting supportive MPs on their actual payroll, and turning the gambling lobby into a career safety net for MPs who lose their seats, is yet another example of the murky revolving door that exists between politics and lobbying. The Mirror has contacted Jack Brereton, Mark Jenkinson and Laurence Robertson for comment. title: ive eaten christmas dinner every
story: Ive eaten a Christmas dinner every single day for  years - its how I stay slimJayne Winteringham, , has stuck to a rigid diet for the last two decades since her kids moved out - but on one special day last year, she made a notable exceptionJayne has stuck to her diet for  years Image: PA Real LeByJessica TaylorReal le features writer:,  Nov | commentsA mum-of-three who has eaten a Christmas dinner every day for  years admits she broke tradition on Christmas Day last year - indulging in a Mexican feast. Jayne Winteringham, , spends time cooking herself a roast virtually every day, complete with Brussels sprouts, carrots and roast potatoes. The only time Jayne deviates from her rigid diet is when sheaposs out at one of her favourite restaurants. The retired nursery worker even claims her consistent calorie intake helps her to maintain her svelte size  figure. But last year on th December, Jayne relinquished control of her diet when she popped over to her daughteraposs house for dinner - and tucked into a Mexican-style dinner.“If I had been cooking, I would have made Christmas dinner. But last year was tricky with the pandemic and lockdowns, Jayne said. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here“I didn’t have a choice because I was a guest and it made a nice change.One day without Christmas dinner was enough for me, though, so I went to the local pub for a full roast dinner on Boxing Day.”Jayne reckons every year, she eats , roast potatoes, , carrots and , Brussels sprouts. She has been obsessed with Christmas since she was a little girl and reckons her love of the festive season in adulthood is down to childhood nostalgia and memories of her mum. She said: “It’s very much an everyday part of my le. It’s such a wholesome, nutritious and tasty meal.“I have fond memories of enjoying roast dinners as a child and I think it’s a very traditional and British staple.“The food available in this country has become a lot more cosmopolitan than it was when I was growing. We have things like pasta, rice, curries, French food, Italian food - while years ago, people’s diets weren’t as broad.“A Sunday roast was an absolute staple. You’d go to the butcher to get your meat and that would last you through the week.“After the roast, youaposd boil the chicken bones and make things like soup and bubble and squeak. So, for me, it reminds me of my childhood.” As a kid, Jayne looked forward to her Sunday roast every week, and carried her love into adulthood by preparing the dish more often.She said: “For the past two decades I’ve eaten it every day - bar December  . It’s just something I never get sick of. She added that, since her kids left home, it became easier to cook whatever she wanted. Thereaposs no one to stop me, she joked. “I think itaposs why I’ve maintained my size  figure over the years, because I consistently consume the same number of calories every day.” Whereas many Brits agree itaposs tricky to prepare a Christmas dinner, Jayne, who has mastered her craft by now, says itaposs a simple issue of timing.  “Time things so they can cook without you having to supervise them too much. Then pop everything in big bowls and put them on the table when theyaposre ready, so people can help themselves,” she said.After years of sampling countless dferent types of Christmas dinner, Jayne now considers herself a roast connoisseur.She said: “I love all kinds of roasts, especially when you go to a carvery and they give you a giant Yorkshire pudding the size of the plate and then you can pile the rest of your roast on top of it.“When I make mine at home it’s very simple. I’ve got it down to a fine art.“I buy everything fresh each day from my local shop and use the meat juices for my gravy. There’s no such thing as a bad roast.“EvenIaposm getting a takeaway, my favourite thing to do is to order a roast from my local restaurant.”However, on th December, Jayne opts to have a rest while her daughter takes over cooking for the day She said: “It’s the one day of the year when I never have to cook for myself. “She’ll always go overboard with it because she loves cooking and serves up a fantastic meal. It ies slightly every year, but as long as there’s gravy, which is my absolute favourite part of Christmas dinner, then I’m very happy. “Good gravy is very important. It can’t be watery and must be tasty. It’s always best when made from the fat of the meat.”Are you Christmas mad  How do you celebrate your favourite time of year  Email jessica.taylor@reachplc with your storiesAlthough Jayne enjoyed her one day without a Christmas meal last year, she hopes toto a proper roast with all the trimmings this Christmas. She said: “Last year was limited with what we could do due to the pandemic, but I’m hoping I can spend this year with my whole family “Of course, the roast dinner will be a big part of the day, not just because it’s Christmas, but because it’s part of my everyday le. “There’s nothing I’d rather eat!” Comment MORE ON ChristmasFoodChristmas dinner" data-immediate"data-immediate"Join the Secret Elves for celebration inspiration - and brilliant gt ideas and reviewsSpread the cheer!Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: baby raised through lockdown surprises
story: Baby raised through lockdown surprises mum with first word - and its very Leanne Howlett said that her baby was born at the height of pandemic uncertainty and they only had each other for company, and soon her daughter uttered her first wordThe young mum was a bit surprised by her daughters choice of word Image: Getty ImagesByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments A new mum who weathered the pandemic with a young baby was shocked when her daughter uttered her first word - and it was aposmaskapos. Leanne Howlett, , gave birth just a few months before the first coronavirus lockdown began, and spent the whole time mothering her daughter - who was just five-months-old in March .She said that all appointments and chances for her daughter to socialise were cancelled, and so the young child didnapost have the same range of interaction as most babies do. As a result when she was learning to talk young Miley didnapost say mummy, daddy, dog, or any of the other popular first words - but instead went for aposmaskapos, as in face mask. What do you think about Mileyaposs first words  Let us know in the comments... Speaking to the BBC, Leanne said: My babyaposs first word was mask.Leanne said that as everything was closed during the first lockdown, her baby had no chance to socialise and learn from other children. She continued: Overnight, home appointments dropped away. She is not at all sociable - she didnapost see anyone but us until she was nearly one. She added that when her daughter did go to her first baby group, all the mums were wearing face masks and she thinks this may have affected Mileyaposs first words.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere.Meanwhile, a young girl made a miracle recovery after living off chicken nuggets for over a decade and now loves to eat fruit and veg - thanks to hypnotherapy. Jessica Thompson, , had an intense food phobia and would suffer anxiety and panic when presented with most foods, but she was ok with beige items and lived mostly on processed chicken nuggets.Her mum, Julia Thompson, , was so concerned she sought out professional help and soon the young girl was diagnosed with avoidant restrictive food intake disorder. At her witsapos end, Julia booked a hypnotherapist to help Jessica, and the treatment was so effective that the youngster now loves eating fruit and veg. Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. title: boy 7 walks circumference moon
story: Boy, , walks circumference of moon twice out of love for terminally ill brotherLittle Reuben has an extremely rare condition that causes his brain to deteriorate and brother Harry has spent the last three months covering more than , miles to prove he loves him to the moon and backSeven-year-old Harry Byrne has gone to the moon and back for his little brother Reuben Image: Sophie Byrne   SWNSByKirsten RobertsonSarah Lumley:,  Nov | commentsA seven-year-old boy has raised over £, for his terminally ill little brother after walking, running, cycling and swimming the circumference of the MOON - twice. Harry Byrne has spent the last three months covering more than , miles with the help of a team of dedicated ‘moon trekkers’, for his little brother Reuben, two. Reuben was born with a condition that causes his brain to deteriorate and so rare it doesn’t have a name yet - and there are fewer than  recorded cases worldwide. Doting brother Harry often tells his younger brother he loves him “to the moon and back”, and wanted to prove it by travelling the circumference of the moon - a feat that he remarkably managed twice. From July  to October , Harry, from Larkhill, Wilts., spent every day ticking off the miles - from walking to school and back, to running a mile around his local football pitch at the half-time of a match. Determined Harry even clocked up an impressive  miles in a single day, when he and his best friend walked from Avebury to Stonehenge - a trek which took them almost  hours. And proud mum Sophie Byrne, , said that all the while, Reuben has been Harry’s “number one cheerleader” - even finishing off Harry’s final mile with him, as Harry pushed his brother’s pram along with his bike. Sophie, who is also mum to eight-month-old Felix, said: “We’re so proud of Harry for everything he’s done. “Not only has he raised money and awareness of Reuben’s condition, but he’s also created all these amazing memories with his little brother, which is just priceless.  “Harry’s favourite parts of the challenge were the bits where Reuben was there with him - like when he cycled the last mile with Reuben, or when I got into the pool with Reuben to watch Harry swim a mile. “We’re not sure how much Reuben can actually see, and he doesn’t really understand a lot of what’s going on around him. “But he does occasionally give a big smile or even a laugh, and that’s when you know he’s really happy, overjoyed - and I think those moments have spurred Harry on a lot in the last few months.” And proud Harry added: “My favourite part was when Reuben and I went on the bike together. I really enjoyed that.  “Some of it was really tiring, but having lots of support from friends made it easier. “I really want to keep raising more money for Reuben, because it makes me feel really good.” Sadly, Reuben is Sophie’s second child with her husband Sean, , to be born with the unnamed, le-limiting condition - which is caused by a PIGB genetic mutation. Nine years ago, the couple had a daughter called Olivia who was also born with the same condition - and passed away aged nine months old, before Harry was born.  Sophie said: “When Reuben was born with the same thing, I knew instantly, because of Olivia. It was like lightning had struck in the same place twice. “As far as doctors know, there have been fewer than  recorded cases of this condition worldwide - and two of them are my own children. “The longest surviving child with this condition lived to the age of just five years old.” But Sophie added: “We’ve always talked quite openly and positively with Harry about Reuben, and about Olivia, too. “It’s something that you can either let take you to a really dark place, or you can turn it into something positive - like Harry has done.  “Things that happen in your childhood can really affect you in adulthood - so we wanted Harry to be able to look back and think of all the amazing memories he created with Reuben. “After Olivia passed away, Sean and I did the Three Peaks Challenge to raise money for the hospices that had cared for her. “And Harry wanted to do something similar to support the hospices that help his little brother.” Harry has so far raised a whopping £, - £, from his ‘round the moon’ challenge, and £, from taking on a -mile walk over three days earlier this year.  The youngster walked between Julia’s House Hospice in Devizes, Wilts., and Naomi House in Sutton Scotney, Hants. - the two hospices that help care for Reuben. And the money he has raised so far will be ided between the two hospices, as a token of gratitude for the work they do. Sophie said: “We’ve been really touched by the generosity of kind strangers during this challenge. “We’ve had a team of about  people over the last three months getting out and donating miles towards Harry’s total, including from as far as Australia and Canada.The Mirror is committed to more hopeful news. We recognise the news agenda can sometimes feel overwhelmingly negative.And while itaposs our job to keep you informed and hold those in power to account, we are making a commitment to also report more hopeful news. We will celebrate the people, places and movements that are bringing good into the world and, more than that, we will dig beneath the surface of important issues with the aim of finding hope.We will be firm in our convictions - but always fair-minded. By sharing solutions to problems, we can do more good and feel better about the world around us. Because we believe you deserve it. #mirrormorehopefulFollow on Twitter @mirrormorehope And follow Mirror More Hopeful on Facebook “We were doing a moonlit walk past Stonehenge one evening in fancy dress, and a passer-by stopped and just handed Harry a £ note when he heard what we were doing. “Harry is very modest about it all, he gets embarrassed when I or others praise him for what he’s done. “People on social media have called him a superhero, but he’ll say, “I’m not, I’m just an ordinary boy”. “But he’s full of energy, so I don’t think we’ve seen the last of Harry’s fundraising yet.”To donate to Harry’s cause, visit the fundraising page on Virgin Money Giving.Comment MORE ON LoveMirror More HopefulRelationshipsCharities" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: couples long awaited miracle baby
story: Couples long-awaited miracle baby died when hospital left tube in him for  hoursLittle Mohammed Rahaan came into the world on November ,  after  weeks and five days and survived only four days with an inquest hearing heard how the tragedy may have been avoideda tube carrying vital fluids into his body had not damaged his liverMohammed Rahaan came into the world on November ,  after  weeks and five days and survived only four days Image: MENByNick Jackson:,  Nov | comments A mum and dad who had been trying for a baby for  years have told how they never want the mistakes that led to the death of their prematurely born son at the Royal Oldham Hospital to be repeated.Little Mohammed Rahaan came into the world on November ,  after  weeks and five days and survived only four days.A Rochdale inquest has heard how the tragedy may have been avoideda tube carrying vital fluids into his body had not damaged his liver causing bleeding into his stomach and ultimately his death. If the misplaced tube had been replaced earlier Mohammed would not have died when he did, the hearing concluded, reports the Manchester Evening News. The hospitalaposs own guidelines said that the tube - known as an umbilical venous catheter- should only be in place for a maximum of  hours. By the time Mohammedaposs condition deteriorated at pm on November , , the tube had been in for  hours.Senior coroner for North Manchester Joanne Kearsley was told that the Northern Care Alliance NHS Foundation Trust, which runs the hospital, had admitted a series of failings in the care of Mohammed.The trust said that it was known shortly after the UVC had been inserted that it was apossub-optimal , but that it was acceptable to continue to use it for a short period of time until the little boy was stable and additional access could be obtained.  The trust admitted that there were aposmissed opportunitiesapos to communicate the plan to gain alternative access and to attempt this from the day sht of Monday, November , apos. It also admitted there was a breakdown in communications between doctors over the replacement of the line and it was not documented in the notes. The handover between medical teams caring for Mohammed was verbal and not documented and the documentation of UVC positioning was apospoor and below standardapos. The trust also agreed that the positioning of the UVC contributed to the rupture of the liver capsule and contributed to Mohammedaposs death. Concluding the inquest, Miss Kearsley said she was satisfied that earlier attempts should have been made to try to establish alternative access. Mohammed was stable on the afternoon of November  and had been stable overnight on the night of the th. The coroner went on: A decision was made to defer the attempt to gain alternative access to the night team. Despite it being a priority that evening no attempt was made to secure alternative access.  We did hear that there were two other babies requiring line insertions and there were clinical pressures. On November  Mohammed was examined but there is no documentation to suggest that by pm, when Mohammed deteriorated, there had been any positive attempts to try to attempt alternative access. We are now some  hours almost from the insertion of the line. I am satisfied that there was an unacceptable delay in any attempt to secure alternative access. There was poor handover and no documentation that Mohammed had a sub-optimal line or of any plan to try to address this. I am equally satisfied that the UVC damaged the liver shortly before his deterioration of November . Once he had deteriorated, the team caring for him were not fully aware of the badly placed UVC, but I accept that it wouldnapost have made any dference by this point. She said: Iaposm satisfied Mohammed would not have died at the time he didit had not been for the sub-optimal UVC line, albeit Mohammed was, in any event, an extremely poorly baby and I do acknowledge the risk of sub-optimal positioning is a noted recognised complication of a UVC line. Ms Kearsley said that Mohammed died due to a recognised complication of a necessary procedure. Despite attempts to save Mohammedaposs le he died in the early hours of November , his death was caused due to bleeding from the liver caused by perforation by the UVC. Ms Kearsley also acknowledged that Royal Oldham Hospital had tightened up its procedures as a direct result of Mohammedaposs death. And she praised the dignity with which Mohammedaposs father Ommar Ahmed and Shabana Kousar, both , had behaved during the hearing. She told the couple, of Meldrum Street, Oldham: Youaposve waited a long time, itaposs nearly two years, but as parents, I canapost imagine how dficult it is waiting for a process. I thank you for your patience and understanding and the way that youaposve conducted yourselves in court today. It mustaposve been very dficult to listen to some of the evidence. After the hearing, Ommar told the Manchester Evening News: Our main concern is that these mistakes never get repeated again so that another family doesnapost have to go through the pain that we have. And he revealed the Mohammed had been born after a decade of the couple trying to start a family. Almost exactly a year later, on October , , their daughter Ayat Ahmed was born. We will never forget her older brother and he will always ben in our hearts, said Ommar, a security worker. A Northern Care Alliance NHS Trust spokesperson said after the hearing: “We would like to offer our sincere condolences to Mohammed’s family for their loss. Mohammed died of a recognised complication of a necessary medical procedure but we accept that there were failings in his care and we would like to apologise to his family for this. As an organisation we are committed to learning and steps have been taken to reduce the risk of similar failings in future, including updates to policy, training, improvements to documentation and audits to ensure compliance.” Comment MORE ON November HospitalsStarting a family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news dad-who-mooned-speed-camera-"University lecturer arrested for flashing bum at speed cameraByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov A terminally-ill dad who was arrested for mooning a speed camera as part of a bucket list item now says heaposs added streaking naked a Premiership rugby match to his list. Darrell Meekcom, , says he has no regrets about showing his bum to a mobile speed van on November , despite police coming to his house minutes later to arrest him. His we Sarah, , filmed the arrest where the university lecturer and registered nurse is brought to the ground by six officers in their back garden in Kidderminster, Worcs. The disabled dad-of-two drew up a list of things he wanted to do before he died after he was diagnosed with multiple system atrophy last month. Mooning a speed camera for a laugh was one item, but now Darrell has vowed to go a step further and streak at a Worcester Warriors rugby game.  Darrell, who uses a wheelchair, said: I donapost regret anything and Iaposd do it again. I still maintain those officers have completely overreacted because I still havenapost seen anything about a law against mooning. If anything it has inspired me for another item on my bucket list which is to streak at a Worcester Warriors match. I canapost run though, so Iaposm going to need a mate to run on and push me in my wheelchair. They have got to streak too though so I just need some volunteers. Iaposve always been a goody-two-shoes nurse throughout my entire le and given my prognosis I now want to let my hair down a little. The other things on my bucket list are to drive a Jaguar XJ around Silverstone, do a bungee jump and a skye. But Iaposm still compiling it as we only came up with the idea last Thursday and on Friday I was arrested for ticking my first item off.  Darrell said he has heard nothing  from West Mercia Police since they stormed his property and arrested him last week. He added: Iaposm still annoyed but Iaposve had a fantastic response from everybody and lots of people are showing me support. It has also hopefully raised some awareness about multiple system atrophy, which I donapost think most people know much about. I try to look at the positives and thataposs why I wonapost be deterred any want to streak at a rugby match. I used to play rugby for many years so Iaposm a big fan and I just think it would be a laugh. Iaposm just concerned about how West Mercia Police might respond though.  Darrell, who lives with his we and two daughters, dropped his trousers at a mobile speed camera van on Stourbridge Road while his we went to a nearby Tesco Express. He was gobsmacked when police showed up  minutes later and arrested him in his back garden. Mobile phone footage filmed by Sarah, a nurse, shows Darrell calmly telling officers: Iaposm terminally ill, I wonapost be able to breathe like this. This is ridiculous - I moonied a speed camera. I moonied a speed camera. A West Mercia Police spokesman said on Tuesday : Around pm on Friday  November officers received a report of indecent exposure on Stourbridge Road. Officers attended and after a search of the area, located a person of interest in Coiey Close. A -year-old man from Kidderminster was arrested on suspicion of public order offences and released on bail. Enquiries are ongoing.Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON West Mercia Police" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: dying mum 33 last christmas
story: Dying mum, , to have last Christmas with her children this weekendBecause she didnt know how long Beck Aspinall had to live, her mum Lisa wanted to bring Christmas forward to celebrate one last festive season together.Becky Aspinall and her son AlfieByAaliyah RuggGraeme Murray:,  Nov | commentsA dying mum is to have her aposlast Christmasapos with her family this weekend. Becky Aspinall, was diagnosed with Huntingtonaposs Disease  years ago when while pregnant with her son Alfie. The condition stops parts of the brain working properly over time, and Becky has deteriorated over the years and is now receiving palliative care.Because she didnapost know how long Becky had to live, her mum Lisa wanted to bring Christmas forward to celebrate one last festive season together, the Liverpool Echo reports.Lisa booked a trip away to Centre Parcs for Winter Wonderland, but her daughter became too ill and now Lisa wants to bring Wonderland to her - with the help from the local community.  The family is looking for old Christmas lights and decorations this week, so by Saturday they can transform their front garden for Becky and Alfie. Kirsty Smith, Beckyaposs best friend, said: Since she was diagnosed, sheaposs just deteriorated over the years. She was in a care home for eight years and because of Covid we had to visit her through the window which was hard, but planning permission was granted and her mum got an extension built so she came home on Christmas Eve. We were so happy when we got her home, we knew she was in the later stages of Huntingtonaposs disease and over the last year sheaposs gotten worse. She canapost walk or talk and recently she lost her ability to swallow. She made the advanced decision she didnapost want a Peg Feeding tube which means sheaposs now at end of le. Her mum Lisa booked Winter Wonderland but sheaposs too sick. Evenshe makes it that long, sheaposs likely to be unconscious by that point. Obviously you canapost put a time on it. So her mum decided to bring Christmas to her front garden. We would like it done by this Saturday because we donapost know how long she will remain conscious. The palliative care team want to up her medication so she will become less and less alert so it is pretty urgent. Beckyaposs family are not asking for cash donations, but instead have set up an Amazon Wish List.Kirsty is hoping to have donations within the next -hours to allow preparations to begin because of Beckyaposs health deterioration. She added: We want to wheel Becky out there with Alfie so they can enjoy a Christmas together. Last Christmas she came home but they couldnapost get her into a routine so it was hard for them, thataposs why this year they wanted to go away but unfortunately, Becky became too unwell. This is her mumaposs wishes so they can spend a Christmas together as a family because Alfie has never really had a Christmas with his mum. Iaposve known Becky since school and Iaposm a nurse now, itaposs sad to think we live completely dferent lives and she hasnapost had the same type of le. We are really grateful to everyone over the years. Weaposve had ious charity events and Becky has done lots of things thanks to people in the community helping. This is one final push for help. title: exact date you should buy
story: This is the exact date you should buy your real Christmas tree and how to make it lastTheres a lot riding on Christmas this year after so many couldnt be with loved ones in , so dont spoil your perfect day with an imperfect tree thats already past its bestThe tree selection process must be rigorous Image: Getty Images Tetra images RFByHarry Thompson:,  Nov | comments With the pandemic causing Christmas celebrations to be cancelled for thousands of families across the UK in , itaposs no surprise that Brits are keen to start getting festive earlier this year. The date for putting Christmas trees up is often hotly debated, with a range of Mumsnet users recently saying doing it early is tacky and vulgar. Meanwhile, in Scotland, a fully-decorated Christmas tree was spotted with twinkling lights in September.When it comes to real Christmas trees, people are often stumped about when to buy one in order for festivities to begin, while also making sure it lasts until the big day.But not this year, because the team at Flowercard have revealed exactly when the right time to buy is to ensure it stays in tip top condition throughout the festivities.When should you buy your real Christmas tree and how long do they last  According to experts, the best time to buy a real Christmas tree is at the end of November, ideally November , for those who wait until January  to take the tree down. Flowercard chief Liam Lapping said: “The day you buy your Christmas tree is one of the most important decisionsyou want to make sure it’s still intact throughout the festive season. The date you buy your tree ies depending on when you tend to take your tree down, as some people do it shortly after Christmas, while others wait until the New Year. “If you take your Christmas tree down straight after New Years Eve then you should buy your tree on the th November. “However,you take your Christmas tree down on the Twelfth Night then you should buy your tree on the nd December. According to Liam, Christmas trees tend to last for up to six weeks, depending on how well they are looked after. When should Christmas Trees traditionally go up  Roman Catholic tradition states that trees shouldnapost go up until the afternoon of Christmas Eve. Liam adds: If you want to follow tradition, then the traditional date to put your Christmas tree up is the afternoon of Christmas Eve, however, we definitely think we need to get in the Christmas spirit before then! Doing things a little earlier than Christmas eve has certainly caught on these days, with a newer tradition of putting trees up at the beginning of advent now common.  The beginning of advent is often regarded as the fourth Sunday before Christmas, meaning that this year it will fall on November . However, many prefer to interpret this date dferently, putting it up on the first of the month, with some regarding it as bad luck for the tree to go up before December. Others take this tradition even further, believing it is bad luck for trees to go up earlier than  days before Christmas. The moral of the story  Get that tree up whenever you want, as long as you time it so that itaposll last until Christmas day. Top tips for looking after your tree Choose the best looking tree: Before you buy your favourite looking fir, make sure you give it a good shake -lots of needles fall off then it probably isnapost the best choice.Trim the trunk : Once youaposve got your new tree in the door, be sure to saw off around cm from the bottom to ensure that plenty of water can be absorbed through the bottom. If it isnapost freshly cut thereaposs a good chance sap will form, limiting the trees ability to take on water, shortening itaposs lespan.Perfect the positioning : When putting it up, make sure you keep it away from any heat sources like radiators and fireplaces as these will dry it out. Keep it out of any drafts too as it wonapost like the rapid temperature changes. Invest in a stand : A good stand will enable your tree to be watered properly.Keep it hydrated : Three pints of water a day is recommended to keep your tree hydrated and to stop sap from forming over the stump.Comment MORE ON Christmas treesChristmasChristmas Day" data-immediate"data-immediate"Join the Secret Elves for celebration inspiration - and brilliant gt ideas and reviewsSpread the cheer!Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: ex supermarket worker lifts lid
story: Ex-supermarket worker lts the lid on ‘stomach churning’ le behind-the-scenesA woman who previously worked in a popular supermarket has shed light on some of the horrors of the job – from cleaning up people’s sick to wasting perfectly good foodThe woman enjoyed working in a supermarket overall - but said parts of the job were far from glamorous Image: Getty ImagesByZahna EklundAudience writer:,  Nov | commentsWorking in a supermarket can feel like a thankless job, but without those people who stack shelves and scan our groceries, we’d be stuck with no way to get our weekly food shopping. One former employee of one of the UK’s most popular supermarkets has lted the lid on what it’s really like to work in a food shop – and some things might surprise you.The unnamed woman, from South East England, worked in a supermarket for seven years until she left in , and The Sun reports she “enjoyed it” overall.And while she may have made some lelong friends in her co-workers, the woman insisted parts of the job were far from glamorous. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. The woman said she worked in ious departments within the store and was also a first aider – which she thought would be a “noble thing” to do until she discovered the truth. She said: “I was a first aider which I thought would be a noble thing to do! However working in a student town, came with student drinking. “This meant I was a gloried sick cleanerI even had a student be sick on me while I fetched him a sick bucket. That would be by far the grossest thing.” The woman also warned customers to always avoid using the toilets at a supermarket, as even the staff-only ones are lacking in the cleanliness department.  And when she wasn’t cleaning up other people’s bodily fluids, the woman spent much of her time being horried at just how much food gets thrown away at the end of each day. The woman claimed it was “gross” to see the food getting binned, and even though she “fought hard” to try and get her managers to give the excess to the homeless, she was always told that it would raise too many “legal dficulties”. She added: “It is quite gross how much gets thrown away though, especially bakery goods. At the end of the night everything gets binned. “When I worked there, I fought to try and get it sent to the homeless, but it came with a bunch of legal dficulties - although I think this might have changed now!” The former employee also had some helpful tips to share with customers, as she said the best times to shop are am - am, am, or pm. She also encouraged customers to “be nice” to supermarket workers, because they can often find themselves becoming a joke amongst staffthey’re rude. The woman even lted the lid on what happens when a supermarket shuts for the night – and it involves the staff playing Supermarket Sweep! She said: “We also held an initiative to improve staff morale called ‘fun at work’. This would involve ious activities that would just give a  min boost of fun to the day.“Being on night shts, there are no customers around, so our fun at work included aisle races and supermarket sweeps. We even held a bike ridefor charity!” Have you got a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: gran 109 carried kickboxing until
story: Gran, , carried on kickboxing until she was  - and only stopped on doctors ordersMerah Smith, born in  and originally from Jamaica, was surrounded by family and friends as she welcomed another birthday - Mrs Smith recommends good food and prayer for a long leGreat great grandmother, believed to be one of Londons oldest residents, celebrates her th birthday Image: SWNSByFlorence Freeman:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA kickboxing grandma, believed to be the oldest woman in London, has celebrated her th birthday. The centenarian, Merah Smith, born in , was surrounded by family and friends as she welcomed another birthday. The former nurse, originally from Jamaica, defied the odds when she regularly attended her local gym every week, up until she was . The grandma had enjoyed regular kickboxing classes and developed a new love for line dancing, but halted her vigorous activities when she sadly developed a knee injury. But despite having to end her gym session, Mrs Smith still enjoys a healthy le, crediting aposgood foodapos and aposprayerapos to her long le. She said: Eating good food like chicken, vegetables and fruit. No stress, but most of all reading the bible, praying and trusting in God. I tell you what, I didnapost expect to live so long but anytime the Lord wants to take me, I trust him, he can take me.  Born in Kingston Jamaica, Mrs Smith had met her husband during the s which she calls her aposfavourite decadeapos - but James sadly passed away from stomach cancer in the s. Despite the tragedy, Mrs Smith migrated to the UK in , having lived through World War  and World War . She is now the mother to three children, grandmother of six, great grandmother of  and a great great grandmother of three. Her daughter, Irene James, , who is sadly recovering from a stroke, shares her love and appreciation for her aposlovelyapos mother.  Worried about Covid affecting her le, she expressed doubts about whether her mother would live so long. But despite everything, Mrs Smith made it the turbulent year without being affected by Covid. Her son Tony Smith, , a retired decorator, knew she would live a long le, believing her good food and faith in God keeps her feeling young. He said: I was so proud when I woke her up this morning - she looked so pleasant and happy. She is so strong and has a sharp memory, and can remember everyoneaposs name in photographs. Iaposm proud of her. But despite her constant positive outlook of le, Mrs Smith found  a particularly hard year, with Covid stopping her from doing many of her much-loved activities.  Mrs Smith said: Iaposve seen many things in my le, but this is the worst year Iaposve been through. Itaposs been dficult because I havenapost been able to go outside. Before Covid, I used to like walking a lot and exercising. But despite the disheartening year, Mrs Smith still maintains her faith, as she calls on people to turn their hearts towards God and change their ways.  And she thanks her children, Tony, Pat and Irene for helping to look after her. Mrs Smith hopes to reach the age of  and with the way le is going for her, she just may reach it.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Birthday party" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: liverpool fan 8 cried himself
story: Liverpool fan, , cried himself to sleep after being refused entry to matchFootball loving Campbell Kaplinsky, eight, had been dreaming of going to see Liverpool FC for the first time before his dad bought two tickets for the West Ham game on November Campbell Kaplinsky, eight, cried himself to sleep after the tickets were taken awayByAbigail Nicholson:,  Nov | commentsAn eight-year-old Liverpool fan was left aposinconsolableapos and in floods of tears after being refused entry to a football match. Football loving Campbell Kaplinsky, eight, had been dreaming of going to see Liverpool FC for the first time before his dad bought two tickets for the West Ham game on November . Dad Ben, bought the tickets for his son as a reward for going to bed on time for three weeks and claims he didnapost know they were for the home end until being told by officials.Ben told The ECHO: He was so excited he wanted to arrive at the train station more than  minutes before the train arrived.He woke up at .am full of excitement and spoke about nothing but the match all day.  The dad and son travelled two and a half hours from Brighton to the Olympic Stadium, with Campbell wearing a red Liverpool shirt under his camo jacket. Ben struggled to keep up with his son as he ran excitedly from Stratford Station to the stadium gates. But once outside Gate C officials took the pairaposs tickets away and Campbell was left aposinconsolableapos. His dad said: I could not believe it as the officials disappeared with the tickets and suspected they may have been sold on for personal profit. The poor boy was inconsolable, locked out the stadium as the best day of his le turned into the worst day of his le. As he went to sleep that night sobbing I did my best to comfort him by reminding him of that timeless Liverpool anthem of strength, hope and resilience – aposthough your dreams be tossed and blown at the end of the storm there is a golden sky and you will never walk aloneapos. West Ham says that home match tickets are for the use by West Ham supporters only. Anyone applying for or using home match tickets must be a supporter of West Ham and not a supporter of the visiting club. The club also says that any inidual who enters any part of London Stadium designated for the use of any group of supporters to which they do not belong may be ejected from the ground either for the purposes of their own safety or for any other reason. The club states that any supporter who purchases tickets must acknowledge acceptance of this and all other terms and conditions, including ground regulations. title: meghan markle admits aide gave
story: Meghan Markle admits aide gave authors help with Finding Freedom - and she knew about itThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex had previously maintained in statement that they "did not contribute" to the bestseller, Finding FreedomA previous statement from the couple said they had not contributed to the book Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByJonathan ColesReporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov Meghan Markle has sensationally admitted a former aide gave authors help with a book about her and Prince Harry - and she signed it off.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex had previously maintained in statement that they did not contribute to the bestseller, Finding Freedom. The biography, which was released in August  and details Harry and Meghanaposs married le and their split from the Royal Family, was supposedly unauthorised. But the Court of Appeal heard on Wednesday that a former aide to the couple did have some communication with the bookaposs authors.Do you have a story  Email webnews@mirror.A statement written by Jason Knauf, who worked as a communications secretary to Meghan and Harry until March , informed the hearing that there had been contact with authors Omid Scobie and Carolyn Durand. In response, Meghan conceded in her witness statement: In light of the information and documents that Mr Knauf has provided I accept that Mr Knauf did provide some information to the authors of the book and that he did so with my knowledge, for a meeting that he planned for with the authors in his capacity as Communications Secretary. The extent of the information he shared is unknown to me.  A previous statement from the couple regarding the book, which was not heard in court on Wednesday, said: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex were not interviewed and did not contribute to Finding Freedom. This book is based on the authorsapos own experiences as members of the royal press corps and their own independent reporting. The bombshell claims emerged as part of an appeal by the publisher of the Mail On Sunday, who maintain that the publication of a letter written by Meghan to her father, Thomas Markle, was lawful. Meghan won a case earlier this year after Lord Justice Warby ruled that Associated Newspapers Limitedaposs publication of her letter to her father was manestly excessive and hence unlawful in a summary judgment - avoiding the need for a trial. The publisheraposs appeal is being heard by Sir Geoffrey Vos, Dame Victoria Sharp and Lord Justice Bean over three days, and the judges are expected to give their ruling at a later date.Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Kensington PalaceMail on SundayMeghan MarklePrince HarryRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
