title: coronavirus in scotland here are the key demographics
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. title: staggering saltire success puts american football side on course for greater goals
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. title: stephen gallacher 600 european tour events
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. title: not-take-rugby-match-borders
story: Another feast of live rugby is taking place in the region and beyond this weekend including a Premiership Borders derby between Selkirk and Jed-Forest at Philiphaugh. Elsewhere Hawick travel to league leaders Currie.In National League Division One Gala will take the long trip to face Highland, Melrose host Ayr, Kelso are in the capital to meet Watsonians and Biggar host Boroughmuir at Hartree Mill.In National League Division Two Peebles welcome Glasgow Accies.In National League Division Three Berwick host Strathmore.In National East League One Duns host Linlithgow.In National East League Two Hawick Linden have a home game against Livingston.In the Tennentrsquos East Reserve League One Hawick Force have an away game at Currie A whilst Selkirk A host Jed-Forest A.In the Tennentrsquos East Reserve League Two Gala A are away to Linlithgow A, Melrose Storm host Watsonians A and Peebles Reds take on Kelso Sharks at the Gytes.In the Semi-Junior Border League Jed Thistle host Tynedale Colts, Selkirk Youth are at home to Carlisle Colts, Kelso Harlequins take on Hawick Youth at Poynder Park, Melrose Wasps host a Borders derby against Gala Wanderers at the Greenyards and Peebles Colts welcome Duns Colts.On Sunday Scotland take on Australia in the second game of the Autumn Series at BT Murrayfield. Kick off .pm

title: peeblesshire-woman-ran-marathon-memory-beautiful-mum
story: A BORDERS woman completed the London Marathon in memory of her "beautul mum" who passed away following a battle with cancer.Fiona Kennedy, from Peebles, ran her first marathon in  to mark her mother completing  years of treatment for soft tissue cancer and to raise money for Sarcoma UK ndash the charity which had supported her mum throughout her treatment.After completing the Edinburgh race in May  and raising pound,, Fionas mum passed away at the age of  in September ."Mumrsquos ethos meant that she took the years of surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and drug trials in her stride," said Fiona. "She continued to travel, play an active part in her grandchildrenrsquos lives and was a much-loved we, mum, sister, and aunt.":Feast of live rugby available for fans in the Borders this weekendAlthough shed sworn to never run again, Fiona, her aunt, uncle and cousins agreed to run a marathon in her mums memory.The family promptly signed up to run the London Marathon  for Sarcoma UK.However, the coronavirus pandemic meant last years marathon was postponed.But despite lockdown, Fiona continued to train for when the marathon was rearranged for October this year.:Man threatened to kill his partner during a bust-up in the Borders"I swore I would never run again after Edinburgh and I crossed the line in London two years later having raised a further pound, for Sarcoma UK," said Fiona."I have been out running in my finishers t-shirt twice since completing London, and I have felt a real sense of accomplishment pounding the pavements in that prestigious t-shirt."Crossing the finish line was a huge sense of relief."My cousin Lucy and I crossed it together hand in hand and promptly burst into tears."The sense of achievement was felt immediately, not least because the staff, marshals and volunteers were amazing in their support and care."The congratulations came from runners, supports and strangers..remove"Mum wasnrsquot at the finish line in London but Irsquom sure she would have been amazed and proud in equal measures.":Photo Gallery: Some of the best Halloween costumes from across the BordersFiona is now looking forward to ing to sports she enjoys, but can also see herself joining in park runs.She said: "I am looking forward to ing to other forms of exercise that I love, but I do see myself factoring in the odd Parkrun to tick my legs over."In terms of fundraising ndash I will have a lelong affiliation with Sarcoma UK."Mum wanted to do more in terms of contributing to research, raising awareness and rising funds, and this is a duty I have inherited."I will continue to look for ways to support the charity I have such fondness for."

title: peebles-choir-appoints-new-musical-director
story: A BORDERS choir has welcomed its new musical director.Peebles-based choir InChorus said it is ldquodelighted to welcome Au Arias to the choir.Au, who is originally from Argentina, has worked with choirs and orchestras in five countries and worked in Turkey for three years as opera director at the Samsun State Opera and Ballet before moving to Scotland with his we last year.Au said: ldquoI have always been interested in big choirs and am very happy to be given the opportunity to work with InChorus in this lovely Borders town.ldquoDespite the many months of being unable to sing together I am amazed at their ability and determination to sound good.The choir spent a number of months without a musical director as the coronavirus pandemic limited opportunities to meet with candidates.Choir manager Cath Shepheard said: ldquoInChorus had been without an MD for some months because the pandemic restrictions prevented our large choir meeting potential candidates in person.ldquoWe thank Au for his patience in waiting for us, and are very pleased that he is with us now.InChorus willto singing for audiences this winter with a performance at this yearrsquos Peebles Christmas Lights Switch On on Sunday, November .They will then sing at Pentland Plants in Edinburgh on December  and at Jupiter Artland Christmas Fair on Sunday, December .Au added: ldquoI have encouraged the choir to take part in some Christmas events to build our performance confidence.ldquoAfter that we will be working on something dferent.ldquoInChorus prides itself in being open to new musical experiences and I intend to give them that.To find out more about InChorus, including how to join the choir, contact Cath at: manager@inchoruschoir, through the website on www.inchoruschoir, on Facebook or Twitter.

title: scott-brash-statue-plans-monument-add-new-dimension
story: THE Olympic legacy of Scott Brash, which was honoured with the erection of a statue, could soon be illuminated with a golden glow.The showjumper landed back in Peebles to unveil the lesize sculpture in recognition of his gold medal back in .The tribute to one of the regionrsquos greatest ever sportsmen was warmly welcomed by the community, and is a spectacular vision on entry to the town from Edinburgh Road.The project was the brainwave of voluntary group Bonnie Peebles, which commissioned the sculpture, which artist Kevin Paxon designed and created from recycled horseshoes.Now, community leaders would like to highlight his golden glory further and hope to work with Bonnie Peebles to clear the final hurdle in this project.During a meeting of Peebles Community Council, members discussed installing lighting at the monument. It was suggested that solar-powered lights would be the most cost-effective option.Tweeddale East councillor Robin Tatler said an application to fund the lighting could be submitted to the Peebles Parking Fees Fund.Chairman Les Turnbull said: ldquoThe Scott Brash monument is a wonderfully impressive artwork at the gateway to the town.ldquoTo have it lit would add another dimension for us all to enjoy, particularly as the nights draw in.

title: sbc-first-local-authority-scotland-use-road-surface
story: SCOTTISH Borders Council is the first local authority in Scotland to use a road surface which is expected to improve durability, a meeting has heard.The surface course specication, TS, is also skid resistant, according to council officer Donald Scott.Mr Scott told a meeting of the Tweeddale Area Partnership on Tuesdaythat TS had previously only been used on trunk roads, with the council the first in the country to try it on a rural network.He also gave an update on the Pothole Pro, trialled by the local authority earlier this year.ldquoWe hope it will be here early next year, said Mr Scott. ldquoWersquore reviewing the best way to deliver that.The JCB machine claims to fix potholes four times quicker than normal ndash and at half the cost.Member of the public Neil McCarroll asked Mr Scott about the standard of repairs, adding that the ldquosame potholes need repairing every year.Mr Scott explained that potholes are split into dferent categories which need to be temporarily dealt with within a certain period of time.ldquoItrsquos very dficult to carry out permanent repairs on seven and -day defects becausewe started to carry out permanent repairs on those we wouldnrsquot get round the network, he said.Temporary repairs are usually carried out by the councilrsquos in-house contractor, but the local authority brought in external contractors in the last financial year ldquobecause of the number of potholes on the network, according to Mr Scott.

title: free-bus-travel-22s-january-says-borders-msp
story: UNDER s will be able to ride the bus for free from January, according to a Borders MSP.Christine Grahame, Holyrood representative for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale, said the announcement will help to meet a key manesto pledge by the SNP in the May elections.Those under the age of  in the Borders will benefit from free bus travel from January .On the announcement, Ms Grahame, of the SNP, said: ldquoThe SNP Scottish Government is once again making an investment in our young peoplersquos future. By making bus travel free for under s in the Borders and across Scotland, opportunities for young people to work, travel and study are being opened up for them.ldquoTravelling by bus is one of the most environmentally friendly ways to get across the country and research shows that young people recognise the vital role public transport will play in hitting our climate change targets.ldquoThis move will not only be vital in our journey to net zero, but will also take pressure off young people and their familiesrsquo finances.

title: scotland-v-australia-channel-scotland-rugby-game
story: Scotlandwill play Australia in their second match of the rugby autumn series this weekend at Murrayfield.Last week the team played against Tonga in front of a home crowd, winning - in an impressive match.Now turning their attention to Australia, the odds look slightly tipped in Scotlands favour, having won the last two matches against the team.With the fansbehind them once again, they will look to repeat last Saturdays triumphant performance as they go against the Aussies for the first time since .As rugby enthusiasts once again fill up the Edinburgh stadium, heres how you can watch at home...Kick-off time for Scotland v Australia match this weekend The Scotland v Australia match will take place at Murrayfield on Sunday November  at .pm.It is the teams second match in the autumn series, which will take place throughout November.What channel isScotland v Australiaand how to watch live Amazon Prime hasthe broadcast rights for the autumn international series in the UK.You will need a membership to tune in, butyou dont already have one you can sign up to a -day free trial.If you dont want to continue your trial after the -days however, you will need to remember to cancel your subscription.When is Scotlands next match in autumn series Here is Scotlands schedule for the autumn series:Scotland v Australia: Sunday November  at .pmScotland v South Africa: Saturday November  at pmScotland v Japan: Saturday November  at pmWhats the Scotland team line-up Stuart HoggDarcy Graham, Chris Harris, Sam Johnson, Duhan van der Merwe Finn Russell, Ali Price Pierre Schoeman, George Turner, Zander Fagerson, Sam Skinner, Grant Gilchrist, Jamie Ritchie, Hamish Watson, Matt Fagerson.Replacements:Ewan Ashman, Jamie Bhatti, Oli Kebble, Jamie Hodgson, Josh Bayliss, George Horne, Adam Hastings, Kyle Steyn.

title: treat-chamber-music-fans-peebles
story: GAIA Duo, Chamber Music Scotlands Ensemble in Residence -, end their Scottish tour at the Eastgate Theatre, Peebles on Tuesday th November at .pm, presented by Music in Peebles.Katrina Lee, a violinist from Yorkshire and Alice Allen, a cellist from Banchory, formed their musical duo partnership  years ago, and have consolidated it during their two years with Chamber Music Scotland, working with artists and composers to forge new works, and to research Scottish female composers hitherto unknown, to bring their music to light.Their programme showcases composers spanning  years including Catherine White Sonata , Ignatius Sancho Selection of Dances, Rebecca Clarke Lullaby and Grotesque, Elizabeth Maconchy Theme and Variations plus works by Sally Beamish and Duncan Strachan commissioned for GAIA.Catherine Whitersquos Sonata was published in Edinburgh as part of a collection by ldquoA Young Lady. Rebecca ClarkeBritish-American, was a virtuoso viola player whose compositions were judged, at the time, ldquotoo beautul to have been written by a woman, and she felt too discouraged to write more.Elizabeth Maconchy,British-Irish, is considered to be one of Britainrsquos finest th century composers with a prolic output, but, as usual, not so well-known yet. Ignatius Sancho was born on a slave ship in  and had a remarkable le.Katrina and Alice are changing the music scene already with their fresh ideas and innovative projects. Both are multi-award winning musicians, are members of several ensembles, and have commissioned several new exciting pieces from Scottish young composers.For more information about these exciting new chamber musicians, please see their website https:www.gaiaduoTickets for th November pound, Discounts pound, Students under  FREEFor information about this th Season concerts please see https:musicinpeebles.org.uk

title: peebles-facilitator-honoured-winning-international-prize
story: A WOMAN from the Borders is celebrating after receiving ldquoglobal recognition by winning an award.Joyce Matthews, who runs her own global facilitation business, won the award for her work developing school leaders with North Ayrshire Council.The ldquoprestigious competition is organised annually by the International Association of Facilitatorsto ldquorecognise the power of facilitation worldwide.ldquoTo be able to challenge the status quo and change the way leadership development has always been done, is empowering for everyone involved, said Mrs Matthews, of Peebles.ldquoIrsquom honoured to receive global recognition for the work I do.:Free bus travel for under s in the Borders from January, says MSPThe Facilitation Impact Awards honour organisations and the people in them that have used facilitation to achieve a measurable and positive impact.Despite a global pandemic, the processes Mrs Matthews put in place with North Ayrshirersquos leadership development workstream meant that the organisation saved thousands of pounds while building a self-sustaining leadership model which reduces the need for external consultants and presenters.A high percentage of teachers who trained as facilitators have now been promoted, demonstrating the improvement of skills and competence of the leaders who have participated in the programme.Andrew McClelland, head of education service, said: ldquoOur work on leadership development and professional learning is sector-leading due to the focus on continual improvement for our own people, by our own people.ldquoWe have made signicant progress in the last  months and are proud to share this work widely.:Peeblesshire woman ran marathon in memory of her "beautul mum"All winners, selected by a global  of facilitation experts, demonstrated the range of projects the skills of a professional facilitator can be used for.Sixteen organisations spanning Belgium, Canada, China, India, Iran, Ireland, the Philippines, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Scotland, South Africa, Switzerland, Taiwan and the United States were recognised for using facilitation to make change and progress happen for their organisations..removeMrs Matthews and the team at North Ayrshire were the only UK recipients of an award.ldquoThe remarkably erse range of projects receiving awards demonstrates our belief that good group process facilitation can be used in any context to help people change the world around them and have an impact, said Vinay Kumar, chair of the IAF.ldquoThe facilitators who have gained recognition for their expertise have combined innovative planning with expert delivery in widely-ied fields to help their clients meet complex challenges and achieve organisational objectives.

title: scots-women-take-japan-dam-health-stadium-sunday
story: BORDERS trio Lana Skeldon, Lisa Thomson and Chloe Rollie have been named in Scotland Women Head Coach Bryan Eassonrsquos -player squad for the upcoming Autumn Test against Japan at the DAM Health Stadiumndash live on BBC ALBA.If they play Skeldon will collect her th cap, Thomson will pick up her th cap Rollie will get her th cap.Easson said: ldquoThe upcoming Autumn Test against Japan is a great opportunity for us to learn from our experience in the Rugby World Cup  Europe Qualiers.ldquoJapan have recently qualied for the Rugby World Cup as the highest ranked team in the Asia qualication process so this will be an ideal test for us as it exposes us to a dferent opponent and playing style ahead of our final qualication tournament next year."The players are also excited to run out in front of a home crowd for the first time since , especially as theyve played mostly behind closed doors for the past  months. Weve all hugely missed having crowds so itll be fantastic to have supporters along at the DAM Health Stadium to cheer the players on."Scotlandrsquos last encounter against the Brave Blossoms was in November , which was also the last match they played in front of a home crowd, with Japan taking the spoils that day with a - win.Eassonrsquos squad recently kept their World Cup ambitions in sight following two back-to-back wins against Spain and Ireland during the Rugby World Cup  Europe Qualiers in Parma.The sidersquos recent success has also seen them rise to an all-time high of ninth in the Womenrsquos World Rugby rankings.Forwards: Leah Bartlett , Christine Belisle , Sarah Bonar , Lisa Cockburn , Evie Gallagher , Jade Konkel , Rachel Malcolm , Rachel McLachlan , Louise McMillan , Lyndsay OrsquoDonnell , Lana Skeldon , Emma Wassell , Molly Wright , Anne Young .removeBacks: Shona Campbell , Megan Gaffney , Sarah Law , Rhona Lloyd , Jenny Maxwell , Holly McIntyre , Helen Nelson , Chloe Rollie , Hannah Smith , Meryl Smith , Lisa ThomsonEvie Wills Tickets for Scotland Women v Japan Women are on sale via the SRU website.Kids for pound tickets are available with a paying adult, at pound, and Us go for pound.

title: peeblesshire-projects-get-cash-part-recovery-scheme
story: TWO Peeblesshire organisations have won funding after successful applications to a council grant scheme.St Ronanrsquos Silver Band will be awarded more than pound, from the Build Back a Better Borders Recovery Fund, while the Walkerburn Bowling and Petanque Club will receive around pound,.However, the Tweeddale Rideability Group was unsuccessful in a bid for more than pound,.On the St Ronanrsquos Silver Band application, a Scottish Borders Council report states: ldquoSt Ronanrsquos would like to purchase  pBuzz instruments and pay for tuition time to provide  children with access to free face to face musical tuition.ldquopBuzz instruments have been designed to encourage children to learn a musical instrument.ldquoTwo -week blocks of tuition will be delivered to  children by a qualied teacher.ldquoThe hope is that this training programme will encourage children to progress to a traditional brass instrument, addressing the bandrsquos gap in recruitment and helping make the band more sustainable.The report adds: ldquoIn addition, St Ronanrsquos Silver Band are seeking funding for the installation of new windows and blinds to their hall as well as the purchase and installation of a new shed.ldquoThe band hall is not currently being used for rehearsals as the windows do not open safely. The band would like to replace the windows with UPVC windows which will allow them to open the windows for the required ventilation following COVID-.Meanwhile, the Walkerburn Bowling and Petanque Club hopes to use the funding to ldquocreate a childrenrsquos practice area and to build a better retaining wall alongside the road.The report adds: ldquoThe club would like to open the club up to more members and improve the disabled facilities. The petanque area has been expanded and is now more user friendly, but better disabled access is needed ndash especially for wheelchair users.ldquoThe club needs to build a level walkway from the clubhouse to the street and to have a better pathway for wheelchairs to negotiate. They would also like to create a childrenrsquos practice area and build a better retaining wall alongside the road. The current wall is in a state of disrepair..removeHowever, the Tweeddale Rideability Grouprsquos application has not been approved.The group wanted to use the money to buy a horse, with the price of new horses ldquogreatly increasing during the pandemic.ldquoThis means where previously costs would have been in the region of pound, to pound, groups iniduals can now expect to pay pound, to pound,, a report states.But the bid was refused due to it failing to demonstrate ldquothe new element of the application.ldquoThe application is looking at continuing a service and succession planning due to the age of current horses as opposed to delivering something new, the report explains.During a meeting of the Tweeddale Area Partnership, Scottish Borders Council officer Kenny Harrow said the group could apply to the community fund as it ldquomight be a better fit.

title: exciting-competition-young-artists-borders
story: BUDDING young artists in the Borders will have the chance to reimagine the facade of Kelso Town Hall.The best designs will be projected onto the building, for two spectacular nights in February between Saturday th and Saturday th, alongside artwork from Borders Art Fair participating artists.A selection of the designs will also be exhibited at the Borders Art Fair in March.This competition is open to all young people, up to, and including, the age of , who live or, go to school in, the Scottish Borders.There will be prizes for the best entries, according to age groups: under s, -s and  years and over.Digital designs should be sent to info@bordersartfairDesigns on paper can be posted to Border Arts Development, Kirkmains Farm, Jedburgh TD TP or scanned and emailed to info@bordersartfair.Moving image designs should be no longer than  secondsPlease include your name, age, address, email address or phone numberApplicants under  must get consent from their parent or legalbefore entering the competition. This competition is free to enter and no purchase is necessaryBorder Arts Development C.I.C. must receive entries by .pm on Monday th December .A template is available as a starting point for and can be downloaded via https:www.bordersartfair

title: 6-points-covid-scotland-update-today
story: John Swinney stood in for Nicola Sturgeon today to give an update on the state of Covid in Scotland to Parliament.The First Minister was absent from Parliament again this week as she continued with COP hosting duties, with the second week of the climate summit well under way.Last weekhealth secretary Humza Yousaf echoed concerns raised by the First Minister in a previous update regarding the rising numbers of hospitalisations with Covid, which reflected the viruss prevalence among the older population.Warnings were issued before COP suggesting that cases could surge after the summit due to the influx of people to the city.However, the Scottish government has repeatedly confirmed it is doing everything it can to mitigate the chances of a rise in infection rate.Following another Covid statement, heres what we learned from todays announcement.... Cases still hovering around , markA further , cases of Covid were recorded over the past  hours in Scotland,meaning cases continue to hover around the , mark.Cases have recently plateaued around this figure following a decline after a surge in the summer due to the easing of restrictions..  million Covid boosters and third vaccinesThe deputy first minister confirmed that as of today,  million boosters and third vaccines had been administered in Scotland.. Number of new cases holding at a concerningly high levelTheres a risk that the spread of the virus could surge againthe past pattern is anything to go by, according to John Swinney.He expressed concern that Covid case rates could rise in coming weeks due to Christmas mingling indoors and with loved ones as the weather gets colder and the festive period nearer.. Cannot rule out "strengthening baseline" measures currently in placeHe confirmed that the government was considering whether to extend the Covid certication scheme to indoor hospitality venues and other areas..removeHowever, the deputy first minister added that no decisions on this have yet been made.. Review of baseline measures will take place a week todayThe three weekly review of the measures currently in place will take place a week today, and John Swinney said they could not rule out reintroducing or strengthening measures.The deputy first minister also took the opportunity to urge people to stick to current guidelines, as well as getting vaccinated and taking regular lateral flow tests.. Covid cases at COP around .%As of November , Covid positivity at COP based on lateral flow tests upon entry to the blue zone was around .%.He acknowledged however we are only just past the halfway point of the conference and confirmed another update would be given following the end of the summit.

title: galashiels-christmas-tree-height-revealed-meeting
story: THE Christmas tree in Galashiels will be shorter than usual this year, a meeting has heard.Galashiels representative Euan Jardine, of the Conservatives, said that Scottish Borders Council was unable to source a ft tree for the town.At a meeting of the community council, Mr Jardine said: ldquoThe Christmas tree is to be delivered and put in place within the next two weeks.:Coronavirus: NHS Borders issues warning amid lsquorisingrsquo number of cases in regionldquoUnfortunately itrsquos not going to be ft, itrsquos going to be ft.ldquoI know some people wonrsquot be happy with that but unfortunately they just couldnrsquot source one.It will be the third consecutive year that a ft Christmas tree will stand in Galashiels.There will be no improvement to the lights in Galashiels this year, or an official switch-on.

title: borders-projects-secure-funding-worth-1-3m-uk-government
story: EIGHT projects across the Borders have secured funding totalling pound. million.Scottish Borders Councilidentied  applications ndash with five unsuccessful and one bid pending a decision.The projects granted funding must be delivered by a deadline of June , .They are:pound, to support the development of environmentally focused courses in entrepreneurship and carbon literacy at Borders Collegepound, to fund an employment and wellbeing programme for people living in housing associations. The Berwickshire Housing programme will deliver digital skills, financial literacy, and promote good mental healthpound, to develop the electric vehicle charging infrastructurepound, for the Scottish Borders Community Development Companyfor workshops to help communities deliver larger scale projectspound, to help the development of a mountain biking centre in Tweeddalepound, for a feasibility study to develop an area of land purchased by Newcastleton and District Community Trustpound, to help support the delivery of training and heritage focused activities by Archaeology Scotlandpound, for the Southern Uplands Partnership to develop energy efficiency training schemesThe money is part of a pound million UK Government funding pot ldquodesigned to support communities to pilot new ideas and approaches to better support people in need.SBC was asked for information about the unsuccessful bids and the project waiting on a decision, but did not supply any details before this newspaper went to press.Council leader Shona Haslam said: ldquoLarge scale projects that are driven by people who live in our communities and are passionate about making the Scottish Borders a better place to live and work can make a real dference to the lives of many.ldquoThe support provided by the UK Governmentrsquos Community Renewal Fund is vital to helping innovative and locally-led projects breathe new le into towns and villages across the Borders and help support the regions recovery from COVID-..removeThe Conservative Tweeddale East councillor added: ldquoWhilst it is great news that eight projects have been successful in securing funding, we will be working closely with those unsuccessful applicants to identy alternative means of taking forward their projects.Conservative Mid Berwickshire councillor Mark Rowley, SBCrsquos executive member for economic regeneration and finance, described the money as a ldquomajor boost to our region.ldquoThe amount of money granted to these inidual projects reflects the strength of their applications and their potential to improve the lives of Borderers by delivering jobs and improving local communities.ldquoItrsquos welcome news to see the timescale for delivery of these projects being extended after a delay to the announcement of funding. This will give much needed additional time to allow our projects to be delivered to their full potential and provide maximum benefit to the Scottish Borders.

title: borders-buses-remembrance-day-closure-affect-services
story: BORDERS Buses has warned passengers that a number of services will be affected by a ldquoRemembrance Day closure.Berwickrsquos Castlegate will be shut between .am and pm for the Festival of Remembrance, according to the travel company.Borders Buses has issued an apology to impacted customers, adding that it is ldquoout of our control.The services set to be affected are:The am from Galashiels will terminate at Berwick Railway StationThe .am from Tweedmouth Retail Park will start from Berwick Railway Station at .amThe .am service from Kelso to Berwick will be unable to serve Golden Square and will ert from the Catholic school to Berwick Railway StationBThe B will ert via Castle Terrace, A, A to the Catholic school. During the closure Borders Buses says it will be unable to serve Castlegate and Golden SquareThe .am service from St Abbs will terminate at Berwick Railway StationThe . service to St Abbs will leave from the railway station

title: half-price-tickets-now-available-see-tapestry
story: THE GREAT Tapestry of Scotland has been awarded Visit Scotlandrsquos Days Out Incentive Fund.The Tapestry tells the inspirational true story of the countryrsquos history, heritage and culture . It was hand stitched by over  people in communities across Scotland and transported by land, sea and air to come together.It is made up of   and  miles of wool .The visitor centre in Galashiels will now be offering half price day tickets from Monday  November  until  February .During this special offer adult tickets will be pound., concession tickets pound., child ticket pound., Burns family ticket  tickets at pound per ticket, Inglis family ticket  tickets at pound. per ticket.Half-price tickets can be purchased online at: www.greattapestryofscotland or in the centre from Monday  November.

title: borders-activists-mark-cop26-weekend-events
story: ALTHOUGH a great number of activists flocked to COP in Glasgow this weekend, environmentalists in the Borders also shone a spotlight on climate issues here.Supporters of the Fridays For Future campaign joined the weekly silent vigil in Melrose in solidarity with the Fridays For Future march which took place in Glasgow, led by Greta Thunberg.As well as the silent vigil, climate activists in the Borders also took part in a series of events over the weekend, including the Great Borders River Clean and the Borders Book Festival.ldquoTheyrsquore all lsquoclimate beaconsrsquo showing we care for the future of the planet, said Greener Melrose chairman Donald McPhillimy of the weekendrsquos events.ldquoWe feel itrsquos good to celebrate this, while COP is happening, so wersquove launched an appeal for groups, organisations, businesses, organic producers etc in the Borders to send us details about their green activities, and how others can get involved.:I know some people wont be happy: Height of Gala Christmas tree revealedOn Saturday, Greener Melrose met with cyclists who had been loaned Ebikes as part of Ebikes for Borderers ndash a scheme to help people seethey would be a suitable replacement to their car for work or leisure purposes.And over the course of the weekend volunteers across the region joined the Great Borders River Clean, helping to collect rubbish and debris from river banks.Volunteers from Greener Melrose were also at the Borders Book Festival recently with a display of their activities and promoting their map of eco-friendly actions being taken around the Borders. This tied in with talks at the festival from Tom Heap who discussed his new book  Ways to Save the Planet and a presentation from journalist Robert Peston about his experiences at COP.A lsquoGreen Beacons of Hopersquo list is being produced in the Borders to highlight what actions are being taken locally to help tackle the climate crisis, to highlight the green activities people can join in with..removeMr McPhillimy said: ldquoJoining with others, to do something positive, is a great start to helping communities be resilient to the effects of climate change, and it feels good to be working with nature, helping restore decades of damage. It certainly beats feeling anxious and helpless in the midst of all the dire warnings wersquore no longer able to ignore. The first step can be to check out whatrsquos already happening.:Services to be affected by lsquoRemembrance Day closurersquo, says Borders BusesGreen activities being included range from growing your own fruits and vegetables to upcycling old clothes and household items.For more information about Greener Melrose activities, the green map and Beacons of Hope listing, contact greenermelrose@live

title: updated-book-commemoration-remembers-gala-woman
story: THE ONLY woman from Galashiels who died during active service in World War II was remembered recently with the publication of the revised edition of the townrsquos Book of Commemoration.Fay T. Currie, an aircraftwomen nd class, WAAF, was only  years old when she lost her le on the th September , following an illness while serving her country. She passed away at Bridge of Larne and is interred at Galashiels Eastlands Cemetery.Gordon Keddie, a volunteer researcher said: ldquoOur group felt it was important those who lost their lives in WWII should be remembered in the same way as was done with those from WWI in , when the book was published.The Book of Commemoration, which lists the iniduals from the town who gave their lives in both World Wars, was produced by Energise Galashiels Trust and has been updated recently following a yearlong project when a group of volunteers researched each of the  men and one woman fallen from World War II, including poignant photos of the townsfolk.The Book of Commemoration is a legacy to Gala Remembers, the extensive programme of activities that took place in  to commemorate the th anniversary of the end of World War I.Debbie Paterson, EGT committee member, added: ldquoWhile the work of Energise Galashiels Trust is often future-focused, it is important that we reflect back in time too, especially when remembering the people of the town who made the ultimate sacrice by giving their lives to ensure we today enjoy our freedoms. We are honoured to be able to continue to support the Book of Commemoration this year with the addition of more detail and images of the WWII fallen.Energise Galashiels Trust would like to thank Jenner McLaughlin, Hazel Hunter, Tommy Turnbull, and Gordon Keddie for their tireless work that resulted in the comprehensive revision of the Book.

title: government-sent-energy-customers-damaging-message-switching-tariffs
story: Energy customers have been sent a ldquodamaging message by the UK Government to switch their energy tarf at a time when this could cost them hundreds of pounds, according to MoneySavingExpert .The Department for Work and Pensionsposted out letters to people likely to be eligible for Winter Fuel Payments, featuring wording on the reverse of the envelopes that encouraged switching energy tarfs to potentially save ldquoan extra pound, the website reported.The messaging said: ldquoWhat would you do with an extra pound The amount was the average saving being made in  by switching to the cheapest tarf on the market at that time.The government iswrongly advising millions of people who get the warm home discount, including many who are vulnerable, to switch energy firm. Spread word that is not correct, the best advice is DO NOTHING .Full explanationhellip https:t.co HtGhGUUWgvmdash Martin LewisNovember , But with the current crisis in the energy market and prices surging, cheap deals have vanished. Customers sitting on default deals are protected by the energy price cap.The envelopes were created before the energy price hikes.Martin Lewis, founder of MoneySavingExpert, said: ldquoWe are in an extreme energy bill crisis. The logic of how to manage bills has been turned on its head. There has never been a time when clarity of message and action is more important. Thatrsquos why the Government mailing out an incorrect message to millions of people, including many of the nationrsquos most vulnerable, is too big a risk to take.ldquoThe right move for most people right now is to do nothing ndash donrsquot switch. Thatrsquos becauseyou do nothing, yoursquoll either be on, or automatically moved to your providerrsquos default standard iable tarf, which is price capped. The price cap forces energy firms to sell energy at below its cost price ndash there is no meaningfully cheaper option.ldquoDue to the obvious hit to their finances, many big energy providers are trying to persuade people to move off those tarfs to fixed deals at premiums often far higher than %. They are using all the marketing tricks in the book to do it, and playing on the fact that until now that has been the right option..removeldquoThis is why this back-of-the envelope message, which seems to confirm that switching is the right move, is so dangerous ndash it adds a halo to the message from the energy firms to get people to switch.A DWP spokesperson told the PA news agency: ldquoWe are committed to supporting low income and vulnerable households to keep warm during the colder months.ldquoWe have encouraged people to switch energy tarfs for a number of years to help them save money.ldquoThe message on these envelopes was simply a suggestion and no further will be issued..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Government sent energy customers  udamaging message u about switching tarfs

title: mp-not-part-time-hobby-say-geoffrey-coxs-constituents
story: A constituent of Sir Geoffrey Cox has said that being an MP ldquoshould be a full-time job while another has questioned his commitment to his constituency.The former Cabinet minister said he does not believe he has breached parliamentary rules after a video emerged appearing to show him undertaking external work from his Westminster office.Labour has referred Sir Geoffrey to the Commons standards commissioner after The Times reported the practising barrister used his MP office in September to participate remotely to advise the British Virgin Islands over a corruption probe launched by the Foreign Office.vw,vw,px, px"A view of the constituency office in Tavistock, Devon, of former Cabinet minister Sir Geoffrey Cox Jenny Davies, a -year-old former nurse and resident in the Tory MPrsquos constituency of Torridge and West Devon, told the PA news agency: ldquoMPing should be a full-time job, especially in a poor rural farming part of the country, not a part-time hobby.ldquoThe worst thing is that he can apparently do nothing for his constituency, fail to attend Westminster, spend weeks in the BVI, and nobody here knows or cares and continues to vote sheep-like for him at every election.Ms Davies added that she had not personally voted for Sir Geoffrey.Another of the MPrsquos constituents called into question his ability to ldquoconcentrate fully on his role and recalled long delays in receiving a response when contacting him.The -year-old manager at a facilities management company, who lives near Tavistock and did not wish to be named, told PA: ldquoI sent an email to Geoffrey Cox which I waited over  days for a response to.ldquoWaiting nearly three months for a response to a query is unacceptable.ldquoI do not believe that Geoffrey Cox is able to concentrate fully on his role as an MP whilst he is carrying out other roleshellip he is not committed to his constituency.The QC, in a statement issued on his website, defended his decision to work with the British Virgin Islands, offering legal advice that could earn him more than pound million this year on top of his pound, MP salary, and said he would co-operate with any investigation into his conduct..removeThe MP of  years said he had been given permission by Chief Whip Mark Spencer to utilise proxy voting rules brought in during the Covid- lockdown to allow him to continue voting in the Commons while working out in the Caribbean earlier this year.Samuel Bedford, a -year-old farmer in Bondleigh and constituent of Sir Geoffrey, told PA that he had contacted the MPrsquos office once before about issues with roads in his area, but was ldquoredirected to a local councillor.ldquoBefore his face was in the newspaperhellip put him in the High Street in somewhere like Crediton, I think people under  would be struggling to place him, Mr Bedford said.ldquoThe general sense from the kind of local area for me is itrsquos a waste of time contacting his office..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Being an MP  unot a part-time hobby u, say Geoffrey Cox us constituents

title: 5-points-covid-scotland-update-today
story: John Swinney stood in for Nicola Sturgeon today to give an update on the state of Covid in Scotlandto Parliament.The first minister was absent from Parliament again this week as she continued with COP hosting duties, with the second week of the climate summit well underway.Last weekhealth secretary Humza Yousaf echoed concerns raised by the first minister in a previous update regarding the rising numbers of hospitalisations with Covid, which reflected the viruss prevalence among the older population.Warnings were issued before COP suggesting that cases could surge after the summit due to the influx of people to the city.However, the Scottish government has repeatedly confirmed it is doing everything it can to mitigate the chances of a rise in infection rate.Following another Covid statement, heres what we learned from todays announcement.... Cases still hovering around , markA further , cases of Covid were recorded over the past -hours in Scotland,meaning cases continue to hover around the , mark.Cases have recently plateaued around this figure following a decline after a surge in the summer due to the easing of restrictions..  million Covid boosters and third vaccinesThe deputy first minister confirmed that as of today,  million boosters and third vaccines had been administered in Scotland.. Number of new cases holding at a concerningly high levelTheres a risk that the spread of the virus could surge againthe past pattern is anything to go by, according to John Swinney.He expressed concern that Covid case rates could rise in coming weeks due to Christmas mingling indoors and with loved ones as the weather gets colder and the festive period nearer.. Cannot rule out "strengthening baseline" measures currently in placeHe confirmed that the government was considering whether to extend the Covid certication scheme to indoor hospitality venues and other areas..removeHowever, the deputy first minister added that no decisions on this have yet been made.. Review of baseline measures will take place a week todayThe three weekly review of the measures currently in place will take place a week today, and John Swinney said they could not rule out reintroducing or strengthening measures.The deputy first minister also took the opportunity to urge people to stick to current guidelines, as well as getting vaccinated and taking regular lateral flow tests.. Covid cases at COP around .%As of November , Covid positivity at COP based on lateral flow tests upon entry to the blue zone was around .%.He acknowledged however we are only just past the halfway point of the conference and confirmed another update would be given following the end of the summit.

title: scotland-v-denmark-kick-off-time-channel-watch-world-cup-qualifier
story: Scotland will play Denmark in their final group stagematch of the World Cup qualiers on Monday night.As it stands, Denmark leads Group F with  points while Scotlandis in second place with ,  points ahead of Israel.Steve Clarkes side will play Moldovaon Friday evening, and a win will mean they guarantee their qualication for the play-offs next year.If they can secure victory over Moldova, it will take the pressure off Scotland for their match against Denmark, who have gone unbeaten so far in the tournament.The top two teams in each group will progress tothe next stage of qualication, with the play-offs taking place in March .With full capacity crowds set toto Hampden Park on Monday night, heres what you need to know about Scotland v Denmark...When is kick off for Scotland v Denmarkmatch Scotland will play Denmark at :pm on Monday November .The match will take place at Hampden Park, Glasgow, making it another home game for Scotland.How can I watch the Scotland v Denmarkmatch on TV The match will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, with subscribers able to stream the match throughthe Sky Go app.People who are not Sky customers can watch via NOWTV by buying a day pass for pound..What position is Scotland currently in Group F as it stands:Denmark:  pointsScotland:  pointsIsrael:  pointsAustria:  pointsFaroe Islands:  pointsMoldova:  pointWhen do the WorldCup play-offs start The play-offs will take place on March  and  .The World Cup in Quatar will start on Monday November  , taking place later in the year than usual due to the high summer temperatures in Doha.

title: scotland-v-south-africa-tv-channel-kick-off-scotland-rugby-match
story: Scotlandwill play South Africa in their third match of the rugbyautumn series this weekend at Murrayfield.Last week the team played against Australiain front of a home crowd, winning -in a close and dramatic match.Now turning their attention to South Africa, the odds looktipped in the latters favour, with the team having won the last six head-to-heads.However, Scotlandcomes off the back of two triumphs and with a home crowd behind them once again, the team will look to extend their successful run.South Africa arrive in Edinburgh following their -win over Wales last week, so regardless of the final outcome of Saturdays match,it looks set to beexciting.As rugby enthusiasts once again fill up the Edinburgh stadium, heres how you can watch at home...Kick-off time for Scotland v South Africamatch this weekend The Scotland v South Africa match will take place at Murrayfield on Saturday November at pm.It is Scotlands third game in the autumn series, which will take place throughout November.What channel isScotland v South Africa and how to watch live Amazon Prime hasthe broadcast rights for the autumn internationalseries in the UK.You will need a membership to tune in, butyou dont already have one you can sign up to a -day free trial.If you dont want to continue your trial after the -days however, you will need to remember to cancel your subscription.When is Scotlands next match in autumn series Here is Scotlands schedule for the autumn series:Scotland v South Africa: Saturday November  at pmScotland v Japan: Saturday November  at pmWhats the Scotland title: send-letters-santa-royal-mail-year--
story: Lettersto Santa can be posted once again this year with Royal Mail, and senders will even receive a reply!Theres no need to try and sendletters up the chimney, just pop it in a post box instead.For -years, Royal Mail has been helping hundreds of thousands of children post their letters to Santa.Heres how you can send Santa letters this year...How to post letters to Santa this year...You can send your letters to Santa this year at the address:Santa Father Christmas,Santarsquos Grotto,Reindeerland,XM HQLetters should be sent by Friday December  to ensure time for response.Make sure to attachfull name and address so senders can receive a reply from Santa.The card from Santa will include a special note from the man himself and a recipe for a gingerbread Buddy the elf recipe.If you cant wait for the response, the card can be downloaded from the Royal Mail website.What are the last datesfor Christmas post Royal Mail is encouraging customers to shop early and post early for Christmas this year.Its latest recommended posting dates for mail to arrive in time for Christmas are:Saturday  Decembernd Classnd Class Signed ForRoyal Mail Tuesday  Decemberst Classst Class Signed ForRoyal Mail Thursday  DecemberSpecial Delivery Guaranteed

title: eggheads-looking-scottish-teams-channel-5-show---apply
story: Quiz show Eggheads is looking for Scottish teams for their next series ndash could you be up to the challenge Applications are now open for the second series on Channel  hosted by Jeremy Vine and organisers are seeking Scottish contestants.The show puts teams against the Eggheads, a group of Britainrsquos most formidable quizzers.Having moved to Channel  with Jeremy Vine earlier this year, contestants will have the opportunity to challenge the Eggheads for a chance at the prize money, which starts at pound, and seersquos an extra pound, added to the jackpot each show the Eggheads win.The most prize money that has ever been won on the show is pound,.Herersquos how to apply for the next serieshellipHow can people apply for the Eggheads Teams of five people can apply for the Eggheads here.One of the team members will be brought as a spare, with only four members competing on the show.Contestants must be aged  or over, with filming taking place between January - .If you manage to beat the Eggheads, yoursquoll win a cash prize.If they win however, the prize rolls over until they can be beaten.Applicantswill be asked for their full name, age, address, phone number and occupation.The application form will also askyou have appeared on TVbefore.You will then be asked for details about your team, including team name, team captain, how your team met, how you came up with your team name and surprising facts about you.It also asksyou could marry anyone from history, who would it be and why Finally you will be asked to upload photos of your team members.When do applications for the Eggheads close Applications for the next series of the Eggheads will close Friday December   at midnight.

title: thought for the week october 15 2021
story: One morning recently, I heard the following two news items on the radio:First was a report about the petrochemical plant at Grangemouth which emits tons of CO into the atmosphere. There are plans to convert it to a hydrogen plant which would capture the CO, send it along a pipeline to Aberdeenshire ready for it to be stored deep under the sea.That was immediately followed by a report on the shortage of CO caused by the increase in energy costs and the closing down of two fertilizer factories which send CO on to other industries, in particular food.How ironic – one industry wants to bury the stuff that others desperately need!I decided to find out more and discovered that CO in ying grades of purity is used in a wide iety of industries.On further research, I also discovered that CO is already being turned from a pollutant into a resource.Companies around the world, including the UK, are reusing CO to make building blocks, cement, foam housing insulation and fuel.I found two examples of companies feeding CO to algae, one to make carbon fibre and the other to revive oyster reefs.#Now it is required that those who have been given a trust must prove faithful.# We are all responsible for the care of our planet, whether as members of faith groups or members of a global society.Refining CO might cost a fortune but not doing so could cost the earth.

title: letters october 22 2021
story: It was great to speak to my constituents in Carradale on my latest visit to the village last Saturday.Many residents mentioned the need to cut the grass verges, especially at junctions, for safety reasons. I have contacted Argyll and Bute Council#s roads management about this on numerous occasions and will continue to do so.I have also been in contact with East Kintyre Community Council about the state of signs at passing places in the area. There are roughly  passing places, some with no signs, some with old and badly deteriorated posts and some with new signs.With the increase in use of many East Kintyre roads, it makes sense to have clearly marked passing places.With more and more people working from home, fit-for-purpose broadband speeds and mobile phone coverage is not just a luxury, but an essential tool for day-to-day le. I have been lobbying BT Openreach and local and national governments for more digital investment in our rural ward.I will continue to work day-in and day-out for our area, making sure voices in Kintyre and the islands are heard.As a clinical nurse specialist on Breast Cancer Now#s helpline, I#m acutely aware of the shattering impact of the Covid- pandemic on the emotional wellbeing of people with breast cancer.News of a diagnosis can be a lonely experience and the pandemic has, at times, exacerbated this, denying people the chance to be with loved ones.We#ve seen a sharp rise in calls to our helpline and emails to our Ask Our Nurses service from people struggling emotionally. Many say the loneliness they#ve felt living with breast cancer during the pandemic has been the hardest emotional impact to cope with and that it has negatively impacted their mental health.As many of us look ahead to a #new normal# beyond the pandemic, we must acknowledge the loneliness legacy facing people who#ve lived with breast cancer through the pandemic and commit to addressing it.This Breast Cancer Awareness Month, we want to remind everyone affected by breast cancer that we#re always with you, in every way we can.Thanks to support from players of People#s Postcode Lottery, our online support services are one click away for anyone after a breast cancer diagnosis.Whether you#re a younger woman, adjusting to le after treatment, or living with incurable secondary breast cancer, our tailored support provides a confidential, safe space to connect with others and access specialist information.Find out more about Younger Women Together, Moving Forward, Someone Like Me, and Living With Secondary Breast Cancer at breastcancernow.org online-services

title: leader october 22 2021
story: It is dficult to understand the Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party#s decision not to allow Donald Kelly to represent the party at the  local election – especially when it will not provide a reason.Councillor Kelly said he met #a wall of silence# when asking for a proper explanation or justication, and the Courier has had a similar experience, with numerous attempts to gain answers proving unsuccessful.We asked why the decision was made and why Councillor Kelly was not made aware or given notice of itit was in relation to his Argyll First membership and why support from former Scottish Conservative leaders Annabel Goldie and Ruth Davidson appeared not to be taken into consideration.If we do receive answers to our questions, we will share them with our readers but until then we can only speculate.Surely Councillor Kelly and the people of South Kintyre deserve to know.Congratulations to Fraser Cursiter and Katie Webster who got engaged this week after Fraser proposed on the beach in Carradale.We wish the couple, who are soon moving to Australia, the best of luck for the future we hope theyto visit the place that has earned a special place in their hearts.

title: thought for the week october 22 2021
story: As we crossed the bridge, we were excited to see the island’s beauty.At first though, we had to take our friend’s word for it, as rain, low cloud and failing light obscured most of it from view. The next day the rain stopped, the clouds lted and the sun broke through.We saw for ourselves that what our friend had said was true. Skye’s scenery is stunning.In John, chapter , verses -, the apostles told Thomas that while he had been away, Jesus had physically appeared to them. Thomas refused to accept as true what they told him, insisting that unless he saw him with his own eyes and touched him with his own hands, he would not believe Jesus was alive.For him, seeing was believing.Later, Jesus once again appeared to the apostles and, this time, Thomas was present. Now Thomas believed. Jesus rebuked him for his unbelief and said: ‘Blessed are those who have not seen yet believe.’We believe lots of things, not because we can see them for ourselves but by accepting the word of those who have.Christians believe in Jesus, not because we have seen him with our own eyes, but because of the reliable word of the apostles who physically saw the risen Jesus with their own eyes.I encourage you to read the Gospels, the accurately written-down eyewitness testimony of the apostles to Jesus so that you might see who he is and as you trust in him alone,

title: cinema prepares of weekend of halloween horrors
story: As part of the national BFI Japan  season, the cinema organised a spooky line-up featuring frightening monster turtles, giant pigs, family anime, whisky tasting, claymation, filmmaking and what is probably the scariest movie of all time.The BFI Japan  entertainment kicked off last Friday, with a screening of Lost in Translation, which was followed by a Japanese whisky-tasting session led by Mark and Kate Watt of Watt Whisky.Tomorrowmorning, children aged between eight and  can get a taste of monster model-making courtesy of Jim Parkyn, lead modelmaker at Aardman Animations, the studio behind Wallace and Gromit and Shaun the Sheep.Jim will help the youngsters create their own monsters, inspired by the likes of Godzilla, the original kaiju – Japanese monster – on film.The children could see their own creations tearing up the Wee Toon as the models will then be used to create a special monster movie which will be screened the following day, on Hallowe#en itself, alongside Gamera: The Giant Monster.Parents are welcome to sit in on the workshop which will last  minutes and will include a chance to ask questions and hear about the master model-maker#s work.The £ workshop ticket includes entry to Gamera: The Giant Monster but spaces are limited and those interested are advised to book as soon as possible.On Saturday afternoon, there will be family anime with Studio Ghibli#s multi-award-winning Spirited Away, considered to be one of the greatest animated films.In the evening, for horror lovers who are brave enough to be scared out of their skins, there#s a rare opportunity to catch the original Ring – Ringu – on the big screen.Ellen Mainwood, Campbeltown Picture House Manager, said: #What more could anyone want of Hallowe#en – giant fire-breathing prehistoric turtle monsters, parents turned into pigs, claymation fun and terrying horror #We#re delighted to be part of the BFI Japan  season, a nationwide celebration of the best of Japanese film.#Tickets for all events, listed below, are on sale now at www.campbeltownpicturehouse

title: from our files october 29 2021
story: Campbeltown#s vital Ring and Ride bus service is safe – for now.It was granted a last-minute reprieve from council budget cuts on Wednesday, two days before it was due to be scrapped.Argyll and Bute Council agreed to continue the Ring and Ride service whilst it takes time to look for an alternative.Councillor Rory Colville, community spokesman for Argyll and Bute Council, said: #We are
